title: Tiger Global co-leads $11m round of Pakistani bookkeeping startup
content: Pakistan-based CreditBook, a fintech startup that provides digital bookkeeping services, has raised US$11 million in a pre-series A round led by Tiger Global and Firstminute Capital. The fundraise also saw participation from Better Tomorrow Ventures, VentureSouq, and other investors.The company says that the round is the largest pre-series A funding round in Pakistan.CreditBook team / Photo credit: CreditBookThe funding round also marks the first-ever investment from Tiger Global and Firstminute Capital in Pakistan’s startup ecosystem.CreditBook aims to tap the rising adoption of digital financial services in the country, especially after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic. It is looking to address a US$45 billion “unmet financing gap” for small businesses, the company said in a statement.The startup’s mobile app is currently used in more than 400 towns and cities across the country. The platform has also seen a 10x growth in terms of transacting users compared to the previous year.CreditBook was launched by Hasib Malik, Iman Jamall, and Hisham Adamjee in July last year.The company will use the fresh funds to focus on value-added features for cash flow management and to strengthen its positioning among small business owners.See also: Series SEA: Who’s investing in the region’s fintech startups?  Other investors in this round include:Ratio Venturesi2i Ventures
excerpt: CreditBook’s fundraise marks the first-ever investment of Tiger Global in Pakistan’s startup ecosystem.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['bookkeeping', 'bookkeeping startups', 'CreditBook', 'fintech', 'firstminute capital', 'funding brief', 'Pakistan', 'tiger global', 'Tiger Global Management']

title: From economics to ecommerce: how Bukalapak’s president joined the startup world
content: When Teddy Oetomo joined Indonesian ecommerce unicorn Bukalapak as its chief strategy officer in 2018, he was caught off guard by the startup’s fluid corporate structure.“When I first started out, we were looking at corporate actions, so I asked, ‘Alright, where’s the corporate finance team?’” he recounts. “Everyone just looked around before looking back at me, and I realized, oh, I guess I’m the corporate finance team.”Teddy Oetomo, president of Bukalapak / Photo credit: BukalapakSince then, Oetomo has rolled with the punches, now looking after several departments in Bukalapak in his current role as the company’s president. He’s become a core part of the firm’s leadership team, helping the company to  list on the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in August this year. The listing made Bukalapak the first unicorn to go public on the archipelago’s home board and was the largest recorded for the bourse.Oetomo’s journey to this point, which involved moving from a traditional finance background to the startup sphere, has been one of learning and unlearning.From economics to ecommerceOetomo started his career as a research analyst in Australia. At the same time, he was pursuing his doctorate degree in economics and teaching at the University of Sydney.“I always knew I wanted to be an equity analyst and felt that the work involved with writing a thesis would help a lot with the foundations for that,” he says.After graduating, Oetomo landed a job at global financial services firm Credit Suisse. He was based in the Indonesia office and worked at the firm for eight years, climbing up the ranks to become the director of equity research. In 2014, he took a year off from his finance career, opting to help out with his family’s business, before joining asset management company Schroders as its head of intermediary business in 2015.Having achieved his initial dream of being an analyst, Oetomo was open to a change in pace. That was when Bukalapak came knocking on his door.“One of the Bukalapak shareholders is someone who I’ve known for over 15 years, and he approached me with this opportunity,” shares Oetomo. “Since I’d spent my whole life in the capital markets and asset management space, it enticed me to try my hand at something a little different.”What was also interesting was Bukalapak’s mission of empowering micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) in Indonesia and its drive to create significant social impact while fueling its own growth as a company.“Bukalapak is an example of doing good by doing well,” says the executive. “It’s not often that you get to do both at the same time.”A different cultureWhen Oetomo joined Bukalapak, the scope of his work was not too different to what he was doing before, but he was not prepared for the culture shock of going from a multinational corporation (MNC) to a fast-moving tech startup.The Indonesian offices of such MNCs typically had 50 people, and all of them came from similar backgrounds, says Oetomo. “When I joined Bukalapak, there were thousands of employees across so many different fields – sales, marketing, programming – it was a very large spread,” he adds.Photo credit: BukalapakAdditionally, the “move fast” approach that Bukalapak adopted with its working processes took him by surprise. In an MNC, there were “rules around everything, including buying a client a cup of coffee,” Oetomo says. At Bukalapak, decisions were often made over calls and chat apps, instead of structured meetings.Joining the startup also challenged a lot of his preconceived notions about what could be done in a company, forcing him to reevaluate a lot of his thought processes and perspectives.“You have to discipline yourself to be open-minded but logical,” he says. “Where I came from, we lived with a predetermined set of rules and have a predetermined perspective of what is doable. When someone comes up with an out-of-the-box idea, we often shut it down without really thinking about it.”Joining Bukalapak forced him to think logically about new ideas and opportunities in order to understand if something really was impossible or if he just wasn’t thinking about it in the right way. This applies to every aspect of the business, whether it’s developing new products or hiring to fill particular roles in the company.“When you’re in a tech startup, you’re going where no one has gone before,” shares Oetomo. “You need people to ask ‘why not?’ And that gets innovation going.”Milestones on the journeyIn the three years he’s spent at Bukalapak, Oetomo has been part of many milestones on the company’s journey, most notably the firm’s listing on the IDX.As an analyst, he spent plenty of time on the other side of the table, reviewing the IPO prospectuses of firms and analyzing them to determine valuations. However, being on the management team of a company looking to go public was a different game.Oetomo and the Bukalapak leadership team at the firm’s virtual Public Expose event in July 2021, where Bukalapak’s IPO plans were announced / Photo credit: Bukalapak“I never appreciated the amount of extra work and pressure you experience being on the management side,” explains Oetomo. “It’s like a house of cards, where you need to make sure everything is in the right place.”This was where his previous work experience came in handy. As Bukalapak geared up for its listing, Oetomo’s knowledge in forming narratives and running road shows made a difference. He helped Bukalapak connect to prospective investors and “sell” its story by bridging the gap between the banking and the management sides of the equation.Taking a company public is a once-in-a-lifetime feat, says Oetomo, adding that “it was a really interesting and rich experience.”Besides the tangible achievements, he is most proud of how the employees under his care – coupled with the opportunities provided by Bukalapak – have grown since joining the company.“When you see how far they’ve come from where they started, how much learning they’ve done, and how they’re now taking on new roles and challenges – that’s quite an achievement.”Making the switchWhile Oetomo’s switch from the corporate world into the startup realm has been a successful one, he’s quick to note that it’s certainly not something for the fainthearted.“It’s rewarding, but there’s a lot of late nights, high intensity, sudden moments where your heart rate starts spiking – it’s hard work, and there’s no free lunch,” he notes.His advice for anyone looking to make the leap is to be aware of what you’re getting yourself into and to be willing to keep an open mind in all situations.“You need to question everything that comes your way because by doing so, we innovate and we do better,” Oetomo shares. The executive believes that this mindset will help when navigating uncharted territory.Indeed, Bukalapak is adopting this approach as it enters its next phase of life as a listed company. In Oetomo’s view, the only way the firm can grow even further is to continue coming up with new solutions beyond what it currently offers.“We need to dare to disrupt ourselves because only by doing so can you go to the next level and really provide the next-level solutions,” Oetomo believes. “As the market evolves, we’ll need to evolve along with it to continue addressing the needs of our customers.”Bukalapak is a leading tech company in Indonesia that serves both online and offline markets, driven by their mission to empower SMEs through innovation and technology to create a fair economy for all.Learn more about Bukalapak on its website.This content was produced by Tech in Asia Studios, which connects brands with Asia’s tech community. Learn more about partnering with Tech in Asia Studios.
excerpt: Teddy Oetomo’s time at Bukalapak has been a journey of learning and unlearning.

title: Shopee launches taxi service in Indonesia
content: Shopee, the ecommerce arm of Sea Group, has launched a taxi-ordering service in Indonesia after signing a partnership with local taxi operator Blue Bird.As with other ride-hailing services such as Gojek and Grab, customers can pay for the taxi service with various non-cash payment methods inside Shopee’s app, including the marketplace’s e-wallet ShopeePay.Photo credit: ShopeeBefore this partnership, Shopee and Blue Bird had worked together on several fronts: The taxi firm allows its users to use ShopeePay to conduct transactions in its MyBluebird app. Also, Shopee’s users could use Blue Bird’s logistics service as one of the delivery methods on the app.The new taxi service is included in Shopee’s transportation and accomodation category, alongside existing ticketing services for hotels, planes, trains, and buses.While Blue Bird was founded in 2001, its history goes back to 1972, when it began providing taxi service with a fleet of only 25 vehicles. It currently is a publicly listed transportation firm present in 18 cities across Indonesia. Aside from its taxi service, the company also has car and bus rental businesses.See also: Sea Group’s financial health in 9 chartsIn 2020, the taxi company invested in Gojek, which had just merged with Tokopedia – Shopee’s archrival in Indonesia. At the same time, Gojek also poured US$30 million into Blue Bird to acquire a minority stake in the business.
excerpt: The ecommerce player teamed up with Gojek-backed Blue Bird for the new service.

title: SG fintech firm rakes in $25m more in series A extension round
content: Sleek, a Singapore-based fintech firm, has raised an additional US$25 million in a series A extension round that was joined by EDBI and some existing investors. The round comes after Sleek raised US$14 million in its series A round led by White Star Capital and Jungle Ventures last month.The Sleek team / Photo credit: SleekSleek makes it easier for a company to manage registration, bookkeeping, taxes, and payroll processes by providing purely digital services aimed at SMEs. The firm said its portfolio has more than 5,000 clients who generate US$10 million in annualized recurring revenue.The company was founded in 2017 by Adrien Barthel, formerly chief marketing officer at Sephora, and Julien Labruyere, former Flybits vice president.Sleek will use the fresh funds to bolster tech and product development, hire new talent, expand its presence in existing markets, and enter new markets.Recently, the startup started offering free business accounts to all of its clients. The Singapore dollar deposit accounts – with automated bookkeeping – collect and process payments. The company also added payment cards to its offerings this month, allowing business owners to easily pay vendors or issue cards to all of their employees for easy expense management.“Since day one, our mission has been to allow anyone to start a business quickly and easily. With the latest addition of the business account feature, now more than ever, we are enabling ideas to become great businesses, without the friction and inefficiency that paper-based and offline processes bring,” said Barthel, also Sleek’s chief growth officer.See also: Series SEA: Who’s investing in the region’s fintech startups?
excerpt: Sleek said its portfolio has more than 5,000 clients who generate US$10 million in annualized recurring revenue.

title: Why Vietnam is missing out on SEA’s IPO party
content: Grab kicked off Southeast Asia’s IPO party on December 2. Even though its listing has performed below expectations, Grab’s achievement could still inspire other IPO hopefuls from the region, including those from Vietnam.Photo credit: GrabThe latest Internet Report from Asia Partners suggests that half of the current 39 unicorns in Southeast Asia could go public in the next decade. After Grab and GoTo, startups like Carousell, Carsome, Carro, Ninja Van may be next in line.But when will tech companies from Vietnam join the party?It’s worth noting that in 2014 – when Grab was still a two-year startup called MyTeksi in Malaysia – VNG and Garena were the only two unicorns in Southeast Asia.Their journeys couldn’t have been more different. Garena’s parent firm, Sea Group, has morphed into a New York-listed titan with a market value of US$140 billion. Shopee, Sea Group’s ecommerce arm, is aggressively growing its empire across India, Europe, and Latin America.See also: How Shopee can succeed in Poland, IndiaMeanwhile, VNG’s global efforts are still relatively nascent. Bloomberg recently reported that VNG was looking to raise up to US$300 million ahead of a potential listing in the US. In 2017, the company signed a memorandum of understanding with Nasdaq for an IPO but its much-anticipated overseas stock market debut has not yet come to pass.In response to questions from Tech in Asia, a VNG representative declined to elaborate on its listing plans.Hot but not there yetIn 2020, Tech in Asia reported that compared to Indonesia, Vietnam’s burgeoning ecosystem had fewer startups raising series A money and beyond.Since then, the landscape has changed significantly.In the first half of this year, the total deal value in the country skyrocketed to US$1.3 billion, according to the latest Google-led SEA e-Conomy report.Data tracked by Tech in Asia also shows that the ecosystem has begun maturing, with the amount of money from series B to C rounds and beyond shooting up considerably in 2021.However, only ecommerce major Tiki has declared its intention to tap the overseas public market before 2025.Tiki’s game plan makes sense as its valuation has reached US$850 million following its series E round. Meanwhile, MoMo’s valuation is expected to exceed US$1 billion as the payment app reportedlyhas bagged US$175 million in funding from Japan’s Mizuho Bank.But apart from these two soonicorns and the country’s existing unicorns (VNG, VNLife, Sky Mavis), Vietnam doesn’t have a lot of high-value tech startups for now. A report by Cento Ventures suggests that there are a few Vietnam-based companies valued at over US$100 million, such as edtech firm Topica, Batdongsan (owned by PropertyGuru), or Misa (which produces accounting software).Among these tech stars, Sky Mavis, owner of the globally popular blockchain game Axie Infinity, is an exception. The three-year-old startup, which is technically considered a Vietnamese unicorn, is not incorporated in the country while most of its users are outside Vietnam.Digital land in Axie Infinity / Image credit: Axie InfinityIn general, “we’re still relatively early in the tech cycle in Vietnam,” says Olivier Raussin, managing partner at FEBE Ventures, an early-stage VC fund based in Ho Chi Minh City. “The companies in Vietnam are privately funded very well and there is no urgent need for an IPO right now.”The sentiment is shared by Joel Shen, a partner at law firm Withers who also co-leads its tech team for Asia. He notes that Southeast Asia has come to the end of its first M&A cycle just as the region’s most mature tech companies like Grab and GoTo reach an exit.Therefore, it’s too early for Vietnamese IPO hopefuls to join the public ride. “Vietnam is probably still behind the curve,” says Shen. “Don’t get me wrong – it’s hot now. Vietnam is like Indonesia in 2015 or 2016.”Regulations are a stumbling blockUK law firm Freshfields notes in this briefing that “an offshore IPO of a Vietnamese company with Vietnamese founders and with its roots in Vietnam would represent an exciting new chapter for Vietnamese enterprise.”The firm, which has been operating in the country since 1994, stresses that Vietnamese companies that are listed overseas “were predominantly foreign-owned prior to their listing and/or operate in other markets.” It also noted that “the listed entities are often holding companies incorporated offshore.”A recent example is US-incorporatedSociety Pass, which claims to be the first Vietnamese company to list outside its home market. The firm has lost nearly 90% of its stock value over the past month.This year, Vietnam has seen some corporations announcing plans to list offshore such as VinFast (an auto unit of VinGroup) and The CrownX (a retail platform of Masan Group).Flashback to 2017: Speaking to Bloomberg, Vietjet Air said that it wanted to be the first Vietnamese company to list overseas. That hasn’t happened yet, and with the Covid-19 pandemic, the budget airline’s goal might be a distant dream.Timing aside, regulations are a major factor in the race to go public, even for major corporations. For example, foreign shareholders are barred from owning more than 50% of the company in certain sectors in Vietnam. The listed entity must be approved by the State Securities Commission (SSC) even for an offshore listing.The SSC requirement, however, can be circumvented if a non-Vietnamese entity is listed.Ecommerce major Tiki aims to tap the overseas public market before 2025. / Photo credit: TikiIn May, Tiki established Tiki Global, a Singapore-based holding firm that owns more than 90% of its Vietnam-based business. The move to be incorporated in Singapore mirrors the approach of Grab, which was originally based in Malaysia. But unlike the super app, which has a regional foothold, Tiki only operates in Vietnam and is still headquartered in the country.Even then, the whole process is still “a very involved piece of work,” says Chris Milliken, an M&A and corporate lawyer at Freshfields’ Ho Chi Minh City office. “If the company decides to list a non-Vietnamese holding company, it’s also about how you put the Vietnamese business into that kind of vehicle.”One of the complications is that Vietnamese businesses might be subjected to foreign ownership limitations in certain sectors, Milliken adds.In terms of onshore listing, he explains that it’s nearly impossible at the moment for most tech companies in Vietnam to make a domestic stock market debut. The country’s amended Securities Law 2019 requires companies to be profitable for at least two years and have no accumulated loss at the time of listing, which is a major challenge for most consumer tech companies, even worldwide.VNG was reportedly aiming to raise up to US$300 million ahead of a potential listing in the US. / Photo credit: VNGOver the past 15 years, only three local tech companies have made an onshore stock market debut: FPT Corporation (information technology, listed in 2006), Yeah1 Group (media network, 2018), and Clever Group (advertising, 2020).Is going public everything?“Vietnam is just at the start of its anticipated boom,” says Vinnie Lauria, founding partner at Golden Gate Ventures. “It’s a market investors will not be able to ignore in the next few short years.”Golden Gate Ventures, which aims to raise US$120 million for its fourth fund, has focused on Vietnam since the mid-2010s. In a report titled “SEA Exit Landscape 2.0,” the firm forecasted a total of 468 exits between 2020 and 2022 for the whole region, with about 80% driven by M&A activity, 15% by secondary sales, and only about 5% by IPOs.Photo credit: Golden Gate VenturesGrab’s current tumble on the Nasdaq might be a wake up call for other IPO hopefuls. A public offering should not be treated as a final destination, and it’s definitely not a route that all companies must take, industry experts say.Still, Lauria is optimistic that the current flow of VC funding to Vietnam can set the stage for “a deep cadre of high-potential listings from Vietnamese firms” soon.But what kind of stories could the country’s IPO hopefuls sell to global investors? VNG, Tiki, and MoMo primarily serve the domestic market – a strategy that Asia Partners refers to as being “Vietnam-only.”“I don’t think it’s necessary for you to have an international business in order to go public but you need to have a story,” says Shen of Withers.For example, GoTo – the merged entity of Indonesian startups Gojek and Tokopedia – hasn’t really flourished overseas. Tokopedia is clearly Indonesia-only, and Gojek is not leading in any of its foreign markets, either.See also: Will GoTo’s SEA story entice enough investors?Nevertheless, GoTo has raised US$1.3 billion in its pre-IPO round.Photo credit: GoTo GroupGoTo serves as an inspiration to a generation of Indonesian entrepreneurs, and it receives much support from local regulators. Last week, Indonesia announced the amendment of rules to allow the issuing of multiple voting shares, rolling out the red carpet for GoTo to head to the public market. Malaysia also recently revised its SPAC framework to “facilitate greater access to fundraising” in the country.“If that’s something Vietnam wants to encourage, it will have to think about whether the IPO rules need to be changed,” says Freshfields’ Milliken. “However, the biggest tech companies may still want to look overseas because that’s where the biggest market is.”But the prestige of an offshore listing is not a given. Just look at the amount of negative headlines about Grab’s falling share price. Its current valuation is now around US$26.7 billion, which is a deep cut from its original price tag of nearly US$40 billion.See also: Grab shares may drop further as more stocks flood the marketWhile Vietnamese tech companies have lured big-name investors such as SoftBank, Goldman Sachs, Warburg Pincus, Goodwater Capital, they will face greater scrutiny and the pressure to perform on a quarterly basis if they list.“The risk of being one of the first few is daunting,” says Nam Le, a principal at Touchstone Partners, a Southeast Asia VC fund that focuses on Vietnam.“Many startups which were established years back do not have the easiest structure to list abroad. The next generation of startups might be more open to [an] offshore IPO, but time is needed for scale.”
excerpt: Many homegrown tech startups dream of listing overseas, but the challenges are immense.

title: How and where to find the best global tech talent (Infographic)
content: Because of the pandemic, companies had to accelerate the adoption of digital technologies in their businesses, and progress in this area is now three to four years ahead of schedule.However, organizations also have to find the right tech workers to support these changes. That’s why the demand for tech talent has heated up and the hiring landscape has turned into a global battlefield as companies seek talent overseas.However, international hiring can be daunting if you don’t know how to go about it. Here’s what companies need to know to win the hiring war over tech talent.Globalization Partners enables companies to hire global remote teams in a matter of days with its AI-driven and fully compliant global employment platform.Learn more about how it can help your global hiring needs by visiting the Globalization Partners website.This content was produced by Tech in Asia Studios, which connects brands with Asia’s tech community. Learn more about partnering with Tech in Asia Studios.
excerpt: Companies need to pull out all the stops in hiring tech talent to stay ahead.
