title: SG music platform bags $53m from Paul Allen’s Vulcan Capital, others
content: BandLab, a Singapore-based music platform, has raised US$53 million in a round led by Vulcan Capital, the VC of Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen. The fundraise also saw participation from K3 Ventures and Caldecott Music Group.The deal, which boosts the company’s valuation to US$303 million, is BandLab’s first founding round that involves external investors.Bandlab app / Image credit: BandlabLaunched in 2015, BandLab’s platform allows users to create music for free, collaborate with other musicians, and connect with their listeners more easily. It also helps independent artists distribute their music through ReverbNation, which BandLab recently acquired.Founded by Meng Ru Kuok, the son of palm oil billionaire Kuok Khoon Hong, BandLab made headlines in 2016 when it acquired a 49% stake in American magazine Rolling Stone through a US$40 million deal. Three years later, the startup snapped upBritish publicationsNMEandUncut.According to a statement, BandLab currently has over 40 million registered users that create more than 10 million songs every month. It plans to use the fresh money for hiring and technology advancement purposes.See also: This made-in-Singapore app with millions of users is democratizing music creation
excerpt: BandLab currently has over 40 million registered users that create more than 10 million songs every month.
editor: Miguel Cordon and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['bandlab', 'K3 Ventures', 'meng ru kuok', 'Startup Funding', 'startups in singapore', 'vulcan capital']

title: YouTube co-founder joins $10m series A of Indonesian automotive startup
content: Otoklix, an Indonesia-based automotive aftermarket services platform, has raised US$10 million in a series A round co-led by Alpha JWC Ventures and AC Ventures, with YouTube co-founder Steve Chen and Sequoia Capital India’s Surge participating.Otoklix team / Photo credit: OtoklixOtoklix helps vehicle owners discover services at nearby independent workshops. It also provides customer relationship management and supply chain management solutions for car workshops.The company was founded by Martin Reyhan Suryohusodo andJoseph Alexander Anantoin 2019. In December 2020, it raised US$2 million funding led by Surge, with participation from GK Plug and Play, Kenangan Fund, Lentor Ventures, and Noble Star Ventures.Otoklix has currently partnered with 1,900 car workshops, and it provided services to over 100,000 customers in the past year. The firm plans to use the new funds to establish its own workshops across Indonesia.Other investors in this round include:Prijono Sugiarto, former CEO of Indonesia-based conglomerate Astra InternationalXA Network
excerpt: Otoklix, which served over 100,000 customers in the past year, is also backed by Alpha JWC Ventures, AC Ventures, and Sequoia Capital India’s Surge.
editor: Miguel Cordon and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['ac ventures', 'alpha jwc ventures', 'funding brief', 'otoklix', 'Prijono Sugiarto', 'Steve Chen', 'surge', 'XA Network']

title: Getting digital done: Hear the stories from two leading telcos in APAC
content: The evolving advancement of technology, changing customer preferences, and growing competition have accelerated the technology advancement journeys for companies of different sizes across various industries.Among them, there are two companies that have been on the forefront of embracing innovation and re-inventing new business model: Singtel and Spark.Watch as Spark New Zealand’s general manager, Kallol Dutta, and Singtel’s senior director of digital and transformation, Derek Lim, discuss their reflections on their respective organizations’ digital transformation journeys, the opportunities and challenges that presented themselves during the process, how the transformation process helped them shape the way they approach future innovation, and how they partnered with Kearney in their journeys.Kearney is a leading global management consulting firm that works with than more three-quarters of the Fortune Global 500, as well as the most influential governmental and non-profit organizations, with the aim of empowering businesses to reap the benefits of digital transformation.Get in touch with the Kearney Asia’s digital team here.This content was produced by Tech in Asia Studios, which connects brands with Asia’s tech community. Learn more about partnering with Tech in Asia Studios.
excerpt: Representatives from Spark and Singtel discuss their organizations’ digital transformation journeys and the challenges they overcame in the process.

title: Lazada delivers $21b GMV in a year
content: Southeast Asian ecommerce giant Lazada clocked in US$21 billion in gross merchandise value (GMV) in the last year till September 2021. Net merchandise value (NMV) – the amount after deducting fees and expenses from the GMV – also soared by more than 60% during the same period, according to the company’s investor day presentation.The Alibaba-owned firm’s user base grew as annual active consumers (AACs) rose 1.8x to 130 million in September 2021 from 73 million in March 2020. Its monthly active users (MAUs) similarly jumped by 1.7x to 159 million from 92 million.Lazada’s monthly selling customers climbed 2.1x during the same period, with its seller base expanding to 922,000 from 443,000. The company’s monthly active selling stock keeping units (SKUs) hit 33 million from 15 million, marking a 2.2x increase.The ecommerce firm says that in the last six months, it has seen a 20% growth in conversion rate as buyer engagement and purchase frequency got a boost.Image credit: LazadaIts livestreaming feature LazLive contributed more than 187% GMV growth on Singles’ Day 2021 compared to the company’s campaign last year. Lazada received 18 million views on LazLive during the mega sale event this year.Its marketing-focused Lazada Sponsored Solutions revenue also surged 5.1x over the last six months. The company’s average seller return on investment on its marketing solutions climbed by 8x to 10x as well.Meanwhile, Lazada Logistics had processed US$5 million worth of daily parcels in September this year. It had also reduced its variable cost per parcel by 27%.The company aims to reach US$100 billion in GMV and to raise its customer base to over 300 million. However, it didn’t specify a timeline to hit these targets.Lazada’s expectations are anchored to the ecommerce boom in Southeast Asia. Citing reports from Frost & Sullivan and the Economist Intelligence Unit, Lazada says that the market is expected grow to US$260 billion by 2025.
excerpt: The ecommerce major saw over 60% growth in its net merchandise value in the last 12 months.

title: Sequoia leads $13m round of Australian instant grocery startup
content: Voly, an instant online grocery startup based in Australia, has raised A$18 million (US$13 million) in a seed round led by Sequoia Capital India. Global Founders Capital (GFC) and Artesian Capital also invested in the company.Voly co-founders (from left) Mark Heath and Thibault Henry / Photo credit: VolyVoly aims to disrupt the local grocery space, which is estimated to be worth over US$88 billion and dominated by offline retail. The startup wants to streamline the process of ordering groceries online by making it as “easy and engaging as browsing Instagram.”It promises to deliver orders in 15 minutes or less. Voly also uses electric bikes and employs its own riders, delivery centers, and store staff.See also: Dark stores light up red-hot grocery delivery market The company was established earlier this year by ex-Uber executive Mark Heath and Thibault Henry, who previously co-founded Balto, a last-mile delivery service firm.Voly plans to use the fresh capital to expand its operations and increase its headcount. The startup offers its services across 42 suburbs in Sydney and is looking to cover more areas in the near future.Currency converted from Australian dollar to US dollar: US$1 = A$1.39.
excerpt: Voly aims to disrupt the Australian grocery space, which is currently dominated by offline retail.
editor: Collin Furtado and Eileen C. Ang
tags: ['Australia', 'funding brief', 'grocery delivery', 'grocery startups', 'instant delivery', 'Sequoia Capital India', 'Voly']

title: ‘Bloomberg for digital assets’ bags $75m from Accel, a16z, others
content: In October, investors piled into a new cryptocurrency inspired by Squid Game, the popular Netflix series. The token’s value skyrocketed by 300% within the first 10 minutes of trading.Five minutes later, the token was traded at US$0.0007 – down from its initial peak of US$2,856.65. It was criticized for not allowing people to resell their tokens, which crypto investors refer to as a “rug pull”.The crash of the Squid token underscores the growing need for analysis and research into cryptocurrencies as investors look to secure their digital assets in a highly volatile market.Singapore-based Nansen, which has been called the “Bloomberg for digital assets” by investors, helps investors make informed decisions around project discovery, due diligence, and trading. The startup recently picked up US$75 million in a series B financing round.The Nansen team / Photo credit: NansenThe company analyses on-chain data points, wallet labels, and entities on blockchains such as Ethereum, Polygon, Binance Smart Chain, Fantom, Avalanche, and Celo, among others.Founded in 2020, Nansen is used by retail investors as well as institutional investors such as Three Arrows Capital, DeFiance Capital, Genesis Block Ventures, Not3Lau Capital, Polychain, YBS Capital, and Acheron Trading.Additionally, it is also used by Polygon, Lido, and Sky Mavis, which runs the popular blockchain game, Axie Infinity – each has seen more than a 20x increase in subscribers over the past year.Stacking coinsAccel led Nansen’s latest funding round, while GIC, Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), Tiger Global, and SCB 10X, which is the tech and innovation arm of Thailand’s Siam Commercial Bank (SCB), also participated. Other investors that joined the round include Amplify Partners, L1 Digital, Skyfall Ventures, Folius Ventures, and Old Fashion Research.Image credit: Timmy LoenAngel investors including Anastasia Andrianova, CEO of Akropolis; Cristóbal Conde, chairman of Fimatix; Adam White, president of Bakkt; and Prabhakar Reddy, co-founder of FalconX, also took part in the round.“It’s a strategic round for us because we got some strong backers on board who can help us break out of the crypto bubble and reach new customer segments, both on the individual side and the institutional side,” said Alex Svanevik, co-founder and CEO of Nansen told Tech in Asia.Nansen will use the funds to hire more developers and research analysts as well as to expand the platform’s features and multichain integrations at a global scale.The firm will also introduce product lines within its platform for new audiences. These include Nansen Query – a product that allows institutional customers to access on-chain data programmatically – and an API product.Additionally, after the fresh funds are raised, protocol teams can publish and access on-chain product analytics via the Nansen Ecosystem offering. Individual investors and crypto funds will also see improvements to Nansen Standard and Nansen Alpha products, including support for over 10 blockchains.Nansen Standard gives access to NFT dashboards, customized alerts, and an Ethereum tracker, while Nansen Alpha gives exclusive access to insights and reports while providing workshops on topics of interest, among other things.See also: Behind the crypto project backed by Temasek, JP Morgan, DBSThe company expects its backers to help it improve its annual recurring revenue using their experience in dealing with startups in Southeast Asia. It will also allow the firm to reach institutional players who can have access to chain data.The rise of Web 3.0 in 2022“While 2020 was the year of decentralized finance and 2021 was the year of NFTs (non-fungible tokens), the biggest trend next year is going to be Web 3.0 gaming,” Svanevik said.He added that Axie Infinity was a “pioneer” in Web 3.0 gaming, with a powerful ecosystem of asset owner guilds and scholars who play the game – even the ones that don’t necessarily own an Axie.The blockchain analytics firm expects an increasing number of companies to replicate the success of Axie Infinity with different types of games. There will also be a surge in the different types of NFTs next year.A screenshot of NFT trading on the Nansen platform / Photo credit: Nansen“We’re only at the beginning of the evolution of NFTs. I’ve spoken to some of the biggest media companies in the world who are actively working on NFTs and have allocated hundreds of millions of dollars to get more active in the blockchain space,” Svanevik said. “They’re trying to figure out how NFTs can be a part of their strategies going forward.”The company also anticipates an explosion of various use cases for NFTs, apart from just being collectibles like we’ve seen this year. Large companies and brands may offer discounts to NFT owners, which could lead to a change in their advertising models.Recently, Nike entered the metaverse with the purchase of RTFKT, an NFT collectibles and fashion startup, whose flagship product is a hybrid NFT and physical shoe collectible inspired by the CryptoPunks NFT collection.SEA at the centre of the metaverseNansen said Southeast Asia has been forward-looking about technological development, with several people potentially leapfrogging the banking sector and going straight into cryptocurrencies.Photo credit: Tech in Asia“This leap forward could be similar to what happened in Vietnam, where people skipped the desktop and went from having no internet connectivity to using mobile apps,” Svanevik said.While several cryptocurrency companies, including KuCoin, CoinGecko, and Zilliqa, are headquartered in Singapore, the gaming scene is strong in Vietnam, where most of Sky Mavis’ team is based.Indonesia, Southeast Asia’s biggest economy, is also emerging as a large mobile-gaming market, with 80% of players in the country using gaming apps once to several times a day.On the other hand, Thailand’s oldest bank, Siam Commercial Bank (SCB), is betting on cryptocurrencies with the acquisition of Bitkub in a deal worth US$536 million. SCB said it will also work with Bitkub to develop new business models for digital assets.
excerpt: Nansen, a Singapore-based blockchain analytics firm, counts Sky Mavis, Polygon, and Lido among its clients.

title: 🇮🇳 Roundup: SoftBank to buy up to 30% stake in Unicommerce, and more (Updated)
content: Startups including Ola, Mohalla Tech, Atomberg, Nexprt, and Hosh have collectively raised at least US$791 million today in disclosed funding from international and local investors.Here’s a snapshot of fundraising:Here’s some important tech news in India today:SoftBank to buy up to 30% stake in UnicommerceSources toldEntrackr that terms of the deal were already agreed upon, with the deal expected to be officially announced soon. Financial details of the deal were not disclosed.The ecommerce enabler was founded in 2012 and was acquired about three years later by Snapdeal for an undisclosed amount.Unicommerce said it currently leads India’s supply chain software-as-a-service industry with a 20% share in the country’s ecommerce volume.Zoomcar launches vehicle host programThe company’s vehicle host program will allow individual vehicle owners to share their personal car onto the Zoomcar platform.Currently. Zoomcar has 5,000 cars on its platform across 8 cities, and expects to grow the platform to over 50,000 cars and 100 cities within the next 12 months.It aims to reduce on-road congestion and urban air pollution through the new vehicle host program, and will also offer individual vehicle owners a joining bonus of 10,000 rupees (US$131.40), along with additional incentives tied to high quality host ratings on the platform.Gupshup launches WhatsApp-based commerce solutionMessaging platform Gupshup has launched a WhatsApp-based commerce solution that can enable any business to create a digital storefront on WhatsApp.The WhatsApp-based commerce solution will provide businesses with a conversational service across every stage of the buying process: pre-purchase, purchase, and post-purchase.Additionally, customers can also add preferred items to their carts on WhatsApp, interact with the businesses in real time, and make payment through Gupshup’s 1-click-bill pay link without leaving the chat window.Follow the rest of our India coveragehere.
excerpt: Also, Zoomcar launches a vehicle host program, which will allow individual vehicle owners to share their personal car onto its platform.
editor: Deepti Sri and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: Byju’s eyes $4b US listing via SPAC merger
content: Indian edtech major Byju’s is in advanced talks to merge with special purpose acquisition company (SPAC) Churchill Capital VII to go public in the US, reported Bloomberg, citing people familiar with the matter.The most valuable startup in India had been looking to fast-track its IPO plans sinceSeptember. It is looking to raise US$4 billion at a valuation of nearly US$50 billion from the IPO. Byju’s is currently valued at US$21 billion.The edtech major had raised nearly US$300 million in October and has spent over US$2 billion in buying 10 companies this year. Its latest acquisition is Austrian edtech firm GeoGebra in a US$100 million deal last week.While the company is expected to announce its SPAC merger in January 2022, the negotiations are still ongoing. Churchill Capital VII has raised more than US$1.3 billion from trading on the New York Stock Exchange since February.See also: Byju’s aims to be profitable by FYE 2022 despite acquisition spree
excerpt: Byju’s is in advanced talks with a blank-check firm that has raised more than US$1.3 billion from trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
tags: ['briefing', "byju's ipo", 'byju’s', 'Churchill Capital VII', 'India', 'new york stock exchange', 'SPAC merger', 'special purpose acquisition company', 'US IPO']

title: Southeast Asia’s VC alliances, explained
content: Sign up for the Daily Newsletter, sent exclusively to our Premium subscribers. We break down the big and messy topics of Asia’s tech and startup community. Get the newsletter in your inbox everyday with a Premium subscription.Hello reader,When I was in school and looking for part-time jobs during the holidays, it was pretty common to see job postings with the phrase “join with your friends” appended to them, especially for places that were looking to hire temporary staff en masse. I’ll admit, it was pretty fun to be working with friends, even if we were just doing boring things like packing goody bags for an event.Much like how I took up jobs along with my buddies, VC firms also invest alongside other investors whose interests align with theirs. There are many reasons why a firm would choose to co-invest with several others – or to not invest with someone at all – but what’s interesting is uncovering the tangled web of these connections, which is what my colleague Tian Wen did.Today we look at,The state of VC alliances in Southeast Asia in 2021A startup that’s trying to make the morning after a night out less painful Other newsy highlights such as what the future could hold for Grab and Cars24’s entry into Southeast Asia  Premium summaryHey buddy!Image credit: Timmy LoenIt’s no secret that VCs invest with peers all the time. What’s interesting, though, is taking a closer look at these connections and exploring the networks that these firms have built. Here’s a look at the state of VC alliances in Southeast Asia in 2021.At the top of the leaderboard: There’s been a significant reshuffling over the past year in the top 20 most active VCs in Southeast Asia in terms of deals made, although the top five most active investors have mostly kept their previous positions.Expanding the circle: According to our analysis, the top five VC firms appear to have become less agnostic over the past year. In this timeframe, VCs have opened their doors to more co-investors and appear to be deepening relationships with new ones.Welcome to the gang: These new co-investors are a varied bunch, ranging from institutional investors to government-linked firms. However, co-investments in Southeast Asia are coming from an increasingly diverse crowd, such as Chinese corporations and VC firms like Kuaishou, ZhenFund, and Boyu Capital, as well as startups-turned-investors like Traveloka and Ovo.Read more: The hidden alliances between SEA’s VCs, uncovered (2021 edition)Startup spotlightCall me when you’re soberPhoto credit: BouncebackHangovers are no fun. The last time I had one, I spent the better part of the day lying in bed feeling very sorry for myself. That’s why some former senior executives at Grab have come together to launch Bounceback, which produces an anti-hangover pill to help folks get back up on their feet after a late night of drinking.All-natural: Launched in September this year, Bounceback’s pill is made of natural substances, with dihydromyricetin (DHM) as its “hero ingredient.” DHM helps metabolize alcohol faster by decreasing blood alcohol concentration and promoting alcohol clearance.Cash in the bank: The firm raised an undisclosed sum in a seed round from investors in September. It’s currently looking to raise another US$3 million in its pre-series A round by January 2022 to get approvals from various health regulators, complete its compliance process, build its inventory, and ramp up hiring.Some lessons from Grab: According to Bounceback co-founder Roy Ang, Grab pushed companies to build communities similar to that of its own. Bounceback has also adopted this approach by distributing its pills at concerts hosted by local disc jockeys, instead of selling them through traditional pharmacies.Quick bytes1️⃣ The journey ahead for GrabGrab‘s first few days on the public market haven’t been the easiest, with its shares ending last week at US$7.12 apiece, which is roughly a 45.5% discount to its opening price on December 2. However, analysts see an easier road ahead for the firm, especially if its mobility segments pick up.2️⃣ Rebel with a causeRebel Foods, an India-based cloud kitchen unicorn, has committed US$150 million in strategic brand investments and acquisitions globally. The amount will be used in the next few quarters to scale up existing and new partnerships with over 40 Indian and international brands. Rebel Foods is currently present in 10 markets, where it operates over 4,000 cloud kitchens.3️⃣ Battle of the used-car marketplaces?India-based used-car marketplace Cars24 is set to compete against Singapore’s Carro and Malaysia’s Carsome as it launches its operations in Indonesia in 2022, marking the start of its expansion into Southeast Asia. Cars24 will invest US$100 million to fuel its expansion plans into newer international markets, after its entry into Australia and the United Arab Emirates earlier this year.4️⃣ Uber charts Didi exitUber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has said that the company is planning to sell its stake in Chinese ride-hailing company Didi. The US-based ride-hailing firm exited China in 2016 after it failed to make a breakthrough in the market and encountered fierce competition from Didi. Eventually, Uber sold its China operations to its local competitor in exchange for a stake.5️⃣ Three-in-one, just like my coffeeThe Hong Kong unit of Singapore-based online classifieds giant Carousell has teamed up with app-based logistics platform GoGoX and buy now, pay later (BNPL) firm Atome to provide services to local businesses via Carousell for Business. Carousell and GoGoX have been working to provide logistics support to sellers through the latter’s GoGoVan and GoGoDelivery services, while Atome helps Carousell’s merchants offer BNPL payment to customers.6️⃣ No FOMO about cryptoSingapore-based payment firm Fomo Pay is joining the DBS Digital Exchange (DDEx) by DBS Bank to enable merchants to accept payments in cryptocurrency from consumers “in a safe and risk-free manner.” Fomo Pay was granted three licences by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for its merchant acquisition, domestic money transfer, and digital payment token services in September.
excerpt: We uncover the alliances between Southeast Asia’s VC firms and look at a startup that’s making a hangover cure.
tags: ['Atome', 'bounceback', 'Boyu Capital', 'Carousell', 'cars24', 'Didi', 'Didi Chuxing', 'fintech', 'fomo pay', 'fomopay', 'gogox', 'Grab', 'hangover cure', 'hangover pill', 'kuaishou', 'Ovo', 'Rebel Foods', 'southeast asia fintech', 'southeast asia vc landscape', 'Southeast Asia venture capital', 'Traveloka', 'uber', 'VCs', 'zhenfund']

title: Ola fuels up with $500m raise via term loan
content: India-based ride-hailing firmOla said it has raised US$500 million through a term loan B facility from international institutional investors.Photo credit: Ola.As part of the proposed loan issuance, Ola has received US$1.5 billion in commitment from backers, though the company has not disclosed details of the investors involved. The funds will go into its business units across ride-hailing, vehicle commerce, food delivery, quick commerce, and financial services.Ola, which rivals Uber in India, has been aggressively raising funds this year, as it looks go public by the first half of 2022. It recently raised US$139 million in its series J round at a pre-money valuation of nearly US$7.3 billion.The capital raise also comes amid a growing need for mobility firms to innovate their product and adapt to the socioeconomic changes brought about by the Covid-19 pandemic. The Indian shared mobility market is poised to grow at a compounded annual growth rate of 56.8% by 2025.See also: A list of India’s unicorns and their early investors (Updated)JP Morgan and Deutsche Bank served as the joint lead arrangers for the term loan.
excerpt: As part of the proposed loan issuance, the company has received US$1.5 billion in commitment from institutional investors.

title: Indian social media firm banks $266m in series G 💰
content: India-based Mohalla Tech, which operates social networking platform ShareChat and short-video app Moj, has raised US$266 million in a series G round led by Alkeon Capital and joined by new and existing investors, including Temasek and Moore Strategic Ventures.Ankush Sachdeva, CEO and co-founder of Moj and ShareChat / Photo credit: Mohalla TechThe latest fundraise, which values the Twitter-backed firm at US$3.7 billion, is Mohalla Tech’s third round in 2021. The company has raised a total of US$913 million so far this year.Ankush Sachdeva, Farid Ahsan, and Bhanu Singh founded Mohalla Tech in 2015.Since its inception, the startup has raised more than US$1.7 billion in eight funding rounds.The company plans to use the fresh capital to focus on social and live commerce services and expand its AI and machine learning team, which currently has more than 100 members spread across India, Europe, and the US.It also aims to generate annualized earnings of US$100 million for the content creator community by the end of 2023 via its social and live commerce initiatives.See also: Where will the new age of social media bring us? Other investors in this round include:HarbourVestIndia Quotient
excerpt: The latest funding round values Twitter-backed Mohalla Tech – the parent firm of ShareChat and Moj – at US$3.7 billion.
tags: ['Alkeon Capital', 'funding brief', 'India', 'india social media', 'Mohalla Tech', 'Moj', 'Moore Strategic Ventures', 'msv', 'ShareChat', 'Social Media', 'Temasek']

title: SG insurtech firm teams up with Pine Labs in Malaysia
content: Igloo, a Singapore-based insurtech firm, announced that it has teamed up with Indian digital payments service provider Pine Labs in Malaysia.Photo credit: Pine LabsThrough the partnership, Igloo can expand further into Malaysia while Pine Labs will offer shoppers mobile phone protection solutions under IglooCare Program, which offers repair and other services nationwide.Igloo’s Mobile Phone 360 and Phone Screen Protection products are available on Pine Labs’ platform. The protection covers repair services and replacement costs worth up to 100% of the gadget’s retail price.Pine Labs currently has over 246,000 merchants in 3,700 cities and towns across India and Malaysia.Igloo has also appointed insurance veteran Amitabh Singh as country manager for Malaysia. Singh, whose nearly 20-year experience includes a stint at AIA Malaysia, will be at the helm of Igloo’s overall operations in the this market.The company will also be hiring for key roles across sales and business development as well as operations and customer service in the country.Igloo has established over 30 partnerships this year across diverse industries in Southeast Asia. In November, it strengthened its tie-up with Vietnamese delivery firm AhaMove by introducing three new products.During the same month, Igloo teamed up with direct-to-consumer healthcare marketplace HD to provide health-related microinsurance products in Thailand via the HDmall platform.In September, Igloo inked agreements with e-wallet platforms GCash in the Philippines and Danain Indonesia to provide online shopping protection and phone screen protection, respectively.In July, Igloo partnered with food delivery platform Foodpanda Singapore to roll out insurance products for gig economy workers.
excerpt: Igloo also appointed insurance veteran Amitabh Singh as country manager for Malaysia.

title: Trip.com swings to net loss of $131m in Q3 2021
content: Trip.com Group, a Chinese travel service major, said its net revenue for the third financial quarter of the year has slumped by 2% year-on-year to US$831 million as Covid-19 re-emerges in certain regions in China.Trip.com logged net losses attributable to shareholders at US$131 million, from a net income of US$251.3 million in the same quarter last year. Its adjusted EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization) for Q3 2021 deflated by around 66.6% to US$84 million.James Liang, chairman of Trip.com Group, delivering a speech at Trip.com Group’s Hong Kong Stock Exchange listing ceremony / Photo credit: Trip.comWhile the company’s accommodations reservation business still stood as its main revenue driver, its results for the quarter saw a decline of 11% to US$341 million from the same period a year ago.Meanwhile, the company’s transportation ticketing business decreased by 5% in Q3 2021 to stand at US$282 million in revenue. However, the packaged tours segment saw a 20% rise in revenue during the quarter to earn US$61 million. Its corporate travel segment also grew by 20%, bringing in US$53 million for the quarter.At the same time, Trip.com’s cost of revenue for Q3 2021 hiked by 19% to US$190 million in comparison to the same period last year. The company attributed this mainly to an increase in compensation to customer service personnel.
excerpt: The Chinese travel major’s revenue also slid 2% year-on-year to US$831 million as Covid-19 re-emerges in certain regions in China.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: JD wiggling into SEA; the fashion industry’s unlikely savior
content: Welcome to The Checkout! Delivered every Thursday via email and through the Tech in Asia website, this free newsletter breaks down the biggest stories and trends in ecommerce. If you’re not a subscriber, get access by registering here.Hi there,As tech writers, we are often intrigued by companies that don’t broadcast their every move.Chinese online retailer JD.com has an impressive market value of about US$122 billion. At home, it has weathered the prolonged tech crackdown well, with its US-listed shares rising nearly 10% in the last six months. In comparison, shares of Alibaba and Pinduoduo have fallen about 40% and 50%, respectively, during the same period.Unlike Alibaba, JD.com generally keeps a low profile in Southeast Asia. Its subsidiary in Indonesia, JD.id, has been opening more offline stores in the archipelago even amid the pandemic. In 2018, the Chinese retail giant made an early bet on Vietnamese ecommerce major Tiki, which has become one of the country’s rare soonicorns.JD.com, unlike Shopee and Lazada, adopts a hybrid marketplace and direct retail model powered by an in-house logistics system. Much like its domestic competitors, the company is also looking to get a bigger slice of Southeast Asia’s booming digital economy.Similar to Amazon, JD.com also wants to tackle the higher-quality segment of products. But Amazon hasn’t really cracked Southeast Asia, while Lazada is splurging to keep up with market leader Shopee.Does JD.com have any room left to play in the region? Tech in Asia’s Tianwen attempts to answer this question in this week’s Big Story, which is also our last for this year as we take a two-week break to celebrate the year-end festivities.With the festive season upon us, some of you might be pondering what to wear. Please allow me to add another option: digital fashion. They’re not real clothes but can guarantee that you’ll look fit and cool on social media.Like what we’ve put in this week’s Hot Take, virtual clothes might be able to solve the fashion industry’s long-term waste problem.Cheers,— HuongTHE BIG STORYCan JD.com make a splash in SEA?Image credit: Timmy LoenAs China’s JD.com ramps up its regional push, its first-party logistics play could be a gamechanger.THE HOT TAKECan digital fashion save the planet?Photo credit: amoklv / 123RFHere’s what happened:SoftBank has recently invested US$150 million in Zepeto, a metaverse platform from South Korea that allows users to dress their avatars in high-fashion items.These include pieces from luxury brands such as Gucci, Dior, and Ralph Lauren, as well as items sold exclusively by K-pop group Blackpink. A Zepeto creator has made US$8,500 a month selling virtual clothes.Luxury brands are already jumping on the metaverse bandwagon, making millions of dollars by producing the digital version of clothes that will likely never be worn physically.“You’re going to have a wardrobe of virtual clothes for different occasions, designed by different creators and from different apps and experiences,” said Mark Zuckerberg at the rebrand of Facebook to Meta in October.Here’s our take:The fashion industry’s sustainability problem is deeply ingrained, accounting for 8% to 10% of global carbon emissions and 20% of wastewater. To further illustrate, it takes about 2,700 liters of water to produce one cotton T-shirt.The boom of fast fashion, and more recently ultra-fast fashion brands like Shein, have made things even worse. Tech in Asia previously chronicled the quiet rise of Shein here.The Chinese brand reportedly churns out 30,000 fashion designs each week. The negative environmental impact is enormous if we quantify the number of items produced based on these designs.Photo credit: Wirestock Creators / ShutterstockAnd it’s not just the environment that suffers – exploitation of garment workers is a major issue. Reports about dire working conditions at Shein, H&M, and Zara are common, and these extend to other fast fashion brands.Recommerce, or resale, has been touted as a driving force toward sustainability. But digital fashion can potentially elevate sustainability to the next level.So what exactly is digital fashion? It refers to virtual versions of fashion items – everything from clothing to shoes and accessories. These items can be worn not only by avatars but also by real people – though not physically.DressX, launched in August 2020, is a retail platform for digital clothes that has raised US$3.3 million in venture capital. On the platform, users can buy digital clothing, have that item weaved into their photos, and make a splash on social media.But what’s the point of doing all this? Some users say digital fashion, which can take on designs that aren’t possible in the physical world, allow them to better express their individuality.It could also digitalize the fashion industry by allowing models and influencers to don clothes for photoshoots without needing to wear the actual items physically.DressX even offers a subscription model and works with Crypto.com to release limited-edition designs.Screenshot from DressX’s InstagramFancy some digital couture? Head to Auroboros, a digital fashion house based in the UK that has the tagline “wear the future now.” The firm uses 3D scanning and augmented reality techniques to create its sci-fi designs, which are then applied to photographs of clients (just to note, clients are real people).While the concept of digital fashion might be strange to some people, enthusiasts believe there are some clear benefits: no production, no oversupply, and no stocks, as well as no boundaries on creativity since designers deal with pixels instead of garments. “The fact that you can create something out of nothing really intrigues me,” Stephy Fung, a 3D designer based in London, told Refinery29.It’s fair to assume that the cost to produce virtual fashion would be lower, which can potentially make luxury items more accessible. However, it’s apparently not the case for now. The digital version of a Gucci bag was recently sold for over US$4,000 – exceeding the price of the actual bag.Skeptics are also wondering whether virtual clothes really can save the planet, given the intense electricity usage that comes with crypto mining. That argument, however, is outdated, as blockchain networks are moving to a far less intensive proof-of-stake model of verifying transactions.For this concept to take off, we reckon it’ll need to look surreal (or bizarre)in some cases. Other users would demand natural look, and it is unclear how high the technical hurdle is to meet these expectations. Finally, there’s the issue of how scalable it is, given that each clothing item will need to be stitched into each photo. To what extent can this be automated?It’s perhaps more likely that digital fashion will take off within the fashion industry first before making its way to consumers.— HuongNEWS YOU SHOULD KNOWCheck out Tech in Asia’s coverage of the ecommerce scene here.1️⃣ Grab is buying Malaysia-based grocery chain Jaya Grocer, which operates 40 stores in the country, for an undisclosed amount.2️⃣ Cars24, a used-car marketplace based in India, plans to launch its operations in Indonesia in 2022, competing against Singapore’s Carro and Malaysia’s Carsome.3️⃣ Flipkart is in discussions to lead a US$100 million round in fresh-produce startup Ninjacart.4️⃣ Temasek Holdings is among the global investors joining Vietnam-based retail platform The CrownX’s latest US$350 million fundraise.FYI1️⃣ Sea could be massive in the metaverse if it wants to beImage credit: GarenaSea’s dominance in gaming and ecommerce, its big bet on finance and payments, and its wager on crypto make it a potentially formidable metaverse player.2️⃣ A closer look at the Lazada mafiaLazada alumni have founded hundreds of startups, but it’s questionable how well the ecommerce firm can tap into this network.That’s it for this edition – we hope you liked it! Do also check out previous issues of the newsletter here.Not your cup of tea? You can unsubscribe from this newsletter by going to your “edit profile” page and choosing that option in our preference center.In the meantime, if you have any feedback or ideas, feel free to get in touch with Terence, our editor-in-chief, at terence@techinasia.com.See you in 2022!
excerpt: The Checkout is Tech in Asia’s free newsletter that breaks down the biggest stories and trends in ecommerce.
editor: Shravanth Vijayakumar, Terence Lee, and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['checkout', 'Chinese ecommerce firms', 'digital fashion', 'dressx', 'JD', 'JD in indonesia', 'jd.com', 'SEA ecommerce', 'The Checkout', 'virtual clothing']

title: Korean blockchain firm gets $60m in series B funding
content: South Korea-based Lambda256, a blockchain-as-a-service (BaaS) provider, has raised US$60 million in a series B round led by Woori Technology Investment. The fundraise was backed by its parent firm, Dunamu, as well as Korean VC firms and investors including Hanhwa Systems and Chong Kun Dang.Lambda256 CEO Jay Jaehyun Park / Photo credit: Jay Jaehyun ParkLaunched in 2018, Lambda256 is the blockchain research and development unit of fintech firm Dunamu, which also runs cryptocurrency exchange platform Upbit. Lambda256 offers enterprise-grade solutions built for businesses across industries to help them navigate the next wave of technology with blockchain.The company has built, deployed, and managed blockchain networks with 3,300 corporate clients through its platform, Lunaverse.“Blockchain’s efficacy in helping companies build trust and transparency with customers across ecosystems is now a foregone conclusion,” said Lambda256 CEO Jay Jaehyun Park, adding that the recent funding will boost the company’s talent pool and accelerate its blockchain road map.Dunamu recently received an undisclosed sum of investment from Hybe, an entertainment agency known as the manager of popular K-pop group BTS.See also: A16z’s first Philippine bet is shaking up blockchain gamingOther investors in this round include:YanoljaDaelimVTI PartnersDSC InvestmentsShinhan Venture CapitalKB InvestmentsSBI Investments.
excerpt: Lambda256 is the blockchain research and development unit of South Korean fintech firm Dunamu, which also runs cryptocurrency exchange platform Upbit.

title: Ecommerce enabler aCommerce files for IPO in Thailand
content: Thailand-based ecommerce enabler aCommercehas filed to sell up to 40% of its shares in a local initial public offering.Paul Srivorakul / Photo credit: aCommerceA correspondent forReuters wrote in a LinkedIn post that the road show for the offer begins with Siam Commercial Bank as the lead underwriter. If the financial debut pushes through, aCommerce would be among the first tech startups to go public in the country.Founded in 2013, aCommerce provides its clients with end-to-end ecommerce solutions, such as those for omnichannel retail, performance marketing, and channel management.It was founded by Paul Srivorakul (group CEO), Tom Srivorakul (group chief revenue officer), and John Srivorakul (former chief technology officer). Since its establishment, the company has onboarded global clients such as Microsoft, Adidas, Samsung, and Unilever.See Also: Ecommerce enablers: Southeast Asia’s next big opportunity?The company recently announced the appointment of three independent non-executive directors to its board leading up to its IPO. This includes Kesara Manchusree, who was the first managing director of the Thailand Futures Exchange and the former president of the Stock Exchange of Thailand.
excerpt: If the financial debut goes through, aCommerce would be among the first tech startups to go public in the country.

title: 3 startups spearheading AI growth in South Korea
content: In a world driven by AI, the jobs we know today may no longer exist in a few years. But with this change comes the creation of new jobs, greater convenience, and possibly an answer to the societal problems we wrestle with today.According to McKinsey & Company, at least 70% of businesses worldwide would have adopted at least one type of AI technology by 2030.However, South Korea aims to be one step ahead of the rest.Photo credit: sepavo / 123RFIn line with its national strategy for artificial intelligence, the government is supporting the nation’s thriving AI startup scene to give those with innovative ideas a platform to bring these to fruition.Likewise, the country’s software industry has come together with Naver Cloud, one of the leading cloud solutions providers in the country, to create an ecosystem to drive growth in the sector. Aside from the cloud data analysis platforms it offers, Naver Cloud also provides consulting on AI solutions, enabling companies to leverage new technologies effectively. It’s expanding its services into Southeast Asia, with the goal of bringing its cloud AI solutions to the global market.Thanks to an abundance of innovation opportunities, generous funding, and a competitive landscape, we’ve seen more South Korean businesses prosper. The country’s startups have raised US$870 million in the first half of 2021 alone – an all-time high for its startup scene.Taking a closer look at this space, we’re featuring three South Korean startups powering new innovations in AI.1. FutureMain: predictive maintenance solutions for smart factoriesWith 36 years of experience as a machine diagnosis engineer, Lee Sun-Hwi, the CEO of engineering company FutureMain, has a clear view of the numerous problems that heavy-industry companies grapple with in machine management.Lee Sun-Hwi, CEO of FutureMain / Photo credit: FutureMainOne such issue is a reliance on outsourced talent to fix machine faults, which Lee says has led to fewer in-house experts having the skills to analyze and detect early problems.“Instead of cultivating analyst talent within their own ranks, most chose to use external experts when faults occurred,” Lee explains. “Because of this, basic faults have snowballed into major repair costs and damages for companies – many of which could have been dealt with in house with the right training.”Combining the big data he collected through his own extensive work history with his mechanical engineering expertise, Lee launched FutureMain to build safer and more comfortable industrial sites for workers.The company’s predictive maintenance solution, ExRBM, leverages AI to automatically diagnose early-stage faults, alert operators, and suggest corrective measures. This helps companies address these faults at low cost and removes the need for them to manually analyze machine data each day.Lee knows that the data collected by ExRBM from organizations’ machines is one of the most important resources for their clients. “To allow for the integrated management of multiple factories and facilities in different locations, we decided to migrate to a cloud-based data collection system,” he says.With Naver Cloud’s support, FutureMain upgraded its solution from being purely “on premise” to also having the capability to be used as a software-as-a-service (SaaS) platform that can be accessed via the cloud, depending on the preference of its clients.The cloud firm also provided systematic training support to help FutureMain launch its cloud service and acted as an extension to the engineering company’s operations, helping FutureMain with buyer discovery and its expansion into overseas markets.FutureMain has grown significantly since its early days – it has received over 12 patents, more than eight certifications, and is the only South Korean-made machine management solution to be certified by the government. And the company is only just getting started.“Through research, development, and global market expansion, we hope to attain an even higher level of growth,” shares Lee.2. TentuPlay: bringing personalized experiences to gamersEvery gamer is unique. Put two of them side by side, and you’ll see that both have different playing styles and motivations, even when they play the same game. Despite this, most titles don’t tailor their gaming experiences to the individual needs of their players.That’s where Kwon Hye-yon saw an opportunity for her startup, TentuPlay.Kwon Hye-yon, CEO of TentuPlay / Photo credit: TentuPlay“We wanted to increase user satisfaction in the gaming world and make games generally more fun by creating personalized gaming experiences, so that every user’s needs and wants are satisfied,” she says.TentuPlay uses an AI-powered behavioral economics platform to identify the motivations of users. Depending on these motivations, it can then send recommendations to the player on the best way to level up or even provide different options to play the game. This leads to increased user engagement, retention, revenue, and lifetime value for the game in question.But TentuPlay hasn’t had the easiest of journeys.“One of the biggest issues with being a small B2B startup is that it’s difficult to meet with larger corporate customers,” says Kwon.What changed this was working with Naver Cloud. The cloud fim “helped us connect with various foreign customers despite being a smaller startup,” she recalls.Since then, TentuPlay has been invited to speak at international game conferences and has been nominated as a finalist in the best tool provider category at the PocketGamer Mobile Game Awards 2021.And as the concept of a metaverse gains traction, the company is making big plans for the space.“The metaverse allows users to partake in various activities such as attending concerts, playing games, and shopping. This can lead to users getting trapped in the ‘paradox of choice,’ leading to churn,” says Kwon.By analyzing user behavior data to identify what they enjoy, need, and want, the firm can recommend content, allowing more users to enjoy the metaverse and participate in the space.3. Monitor Corporation: efficient medical image diagnosisAs a graduate of computer vision technology, Lee Kyong-Joon (no relation to FutureMain’s Lee Sun-Hwi), CEO of AI-powered radiology tech company Monitor Corporation, saw a pressing need in the medical industry. Every year, the number of medical images that are taken increases significantly, while the number of radiologists with the skills to read these images remained low. This phenomenon became more evident as Lee traveled to the rural provinces of South Korea and to other developing economies in the region.Lee Kyong-Joon, CEO of Monitor Corporation / Photo credit: Monitor CorporationTo address this talent shortage, Lee launched Monitor Corporation. Its signature product, LuCAS, uses AI algorithms to analyze chest CT scan images and automatically identifies the location and type of disease. These results allow doctors to provide accurate diagnosis for patients more efficiently.While Monitor Corporation is based in Seoul, it has worked with businesses around the globe, including in places as far away as Brazil, using Naver Cloud’s servers.“At the end of last year, a company in Brazil contacted us saying that they wanted to try our service, but we were not ready at the time,” shares Lee. “In the process of preparing for the demo, we encountered many technical challenges. Naver Cloud provided quick responses so that we could successfully open the overseas service demo.”Building solutions on Naver Cloud’s SaaS platform has helped Monitor Corporation establish partnerships with over 20 domestic and foreign organizations – a number that is set to grow.“​​Based on high-quality medical infrastructure, South Korea is applying cutting-edge AI technologies to the medical market most actively in the world,” Lee says. “We aim to bring these high-quality AI services to the global market.”Naver Cloud operates the global IT infrastructure and enterprise solution service for South Korean tech giant Naver and its subsidiaries while providing its public cloud service, Naver Cloud Platform, to a myriad of companies and organizations in diverse industries.Find out how you can scale your business overseas with the power of Naver Cloud by visiting its website.This content was produced by Tech in Asia Studios, which connects brands with Asia’s tech community. Learn more about partnering with Tech in Asia Studios.
excerpt: From gaming to medicine, AI startups are transforming South Korea.
editor: Stefanie Yeo, Nathaniel Fetalvero, and Jaclyn Tiu

title: This deck got emoji startup a 👍 from investors for $1.5m seed money
content: ﻿ ABOUTMojiLaLa is a marketplace for emojis and stickers. It allows artists and designers to submit their sticker packs to its platform. Collectively, there are over 50,000 stickers to choose from on MojiLaLa’s marketplace.Founded by Dana Loberg and Sahin Boydas in 2015, the startup is backed by 500 Global (formerly 500 Startups) and was part of the VC’s Batch 19 cohort in 2016.MojiLaLa used this pitch deck for its seed funding round.Fundraising journey2017: US$1.5 million of seed funding from Great Oaks Venture Capital and Betaworks Ventures, as well as from IVP partner Dennis PhelpsHow is the deck compelling?The deck begins by showing how the emoji phenomenon has attracted global attention. It then highlights how disconnected emoji designers are with the chat platforms that carry their creations.It points out how MojiLaLa addresses this issue and how much the company scaled in only six months. The deck also shows the startup’s distribution channels.The deck concludes by introducing MojiLala’s key members and summarizing the figures that were mentioned throughout the presentation.SOURCEDeck: AngelMatch
excerpt: MojiLaLa is backed by 500 Global (formerly 500 Startups) and was part of the VC’s Batch 19 cohort in 2016.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: Can JD.com make a splash in SEA?
content: Earlier this year, shoppers at Aeon Mall Sentul City in West Java were treated to the grand opening of JD.com’s first overseas E-Space store, which primarily sells electronics and home appliance products.It’s not the Chinese ecommerce major’s first foray into Indonesia, where Tokopedia and Shopee are the dominant players. Local subsidiary JD.id has been up and running since 2015, and it opened five other physical retail outlets in key cities across the archipelago even amid the pandemic.Photo credit: ShutterstockCompared to its rivals like Alibaba and Pinduoduo, JD has fared better in China despite the tech crackdown spearheaded by the country’s regulators. The company also reported US$34.3 billion in revenue for the third quarter of this year, exceeding analyst estimates by a slight margin.For years, JD.com has been perceived as less ambitious than other Chinese firms when it comes to international expansion.But that might be changing. Recently, a top JD executive told CNBC that the firm is looking to ramp up investments abroad. Vietnam and Europe have been singled out as potential expansion locations.JD, which has a market capitalization of about US$122 billion, generally keeps a low profile in Southeast Asia. Soon Sze Meng, its chief for the region, also recently left to join a cloud kitchen startup.Given these circumstances, is JD serious about Southeast Asia? And is there any room for it to play here?A sleeping dragonFor sure, JD’s presence in the region is not as clearly seen as Alibaba’s.Two years after launching JD.id in 2015, the company entered into a joint venture with Thailand’s Central Group and opened brick-and-mortar stores in Indonesia.Beyond expanding its physical footprint, the company also beefed up its online presence by rolling out JD Central in 2018. At the same time, it has invested in regional leaders like Vietnam’s Tiki Corporation and Thailand’s fashion ecommerce Pomelo since 2017.It’s safe to say that JD’s regional thrust has largely been driven by joint ventures and strategic investments into local ecommerce players.Meanwhile, Alibaba – its closest Chinese competitor – has injected about US$4.4 billion into Lazada between 2018 and 2020, with more than US$2 billion in 2020 alone. It’s not clear, though, how much of that money was spent on operations.See also: Alibaba and Tencent’s growing tentacles in Southeast AsiaJD is “not moving fast enough” in Southeast Asia, and that lack of speed is the company’s biggest challenge in the region, says Jeffrey Towson, a professor at Bangkok’s Sasin School of Management. “It’s not building consumer engagement at the same level of its competitors … nor [is it] making big enough capital commitments,” he explains.The firm’s sluggish pace may also be a deliberate choice, explains Towson, who studiesdigital trends in China. It’s likely that JD wouldn’t engage in the spending war between rivals Shopee and Lazada, opting to wait for a more opportune moment to strike, he adds.Josh Gardner, CEO of Beijing-based ecommerce consultancy firm Kung Fu Data, echoes this view. “JD has been waiting until its model is perfect for Southeast Asia,” says the executive, who has been watching China’s ecommerce and retail scene for more than seven years.Unlike Lazada and Shopee’s marketplace commerce model, JD adopts a hybrid marketplace-direct retail model that’s powered by an in-house logistics system.Gardner points out that it would be “strategically very smart” for JD to make bigger bets in the region now. Domestic pressures, which include the Chinese government’s ongoing tech clampdown and slowing online spending in China, means that JD needs to act on its international ambition before it’s too late.China’s current situation is a stark contrast to Southeast Asia, where ecommerce is expected to be the main driver of the region’s US$174 billion gross merchandise value in 2021, according to the latest Google, Temasek, Bain & Company e-Conomy SEA report.JD.com currently holds about 17% of China’s retail ecommerce market, according to estimates by eMarketer. That’s a sharp drop from 24.7% four years earlier, and it’s mostly due to social commerce heavyweights like Pinduoduo – the pioneer in community-group buying – breathing down its neck.Can O2O win the day?Tech in Asia reached out to JD for this story but did not receive a reply.However, Eyvette Tung, head of offline business at JD.id, told TIA that the online-to-offline (O2O) business remains an important component to the company’s Indonesian operations.Physical retail sales have taken a hit due to pandemic lockdowns, but offline channels still comprise nearly 80% of Indonesia’s retail market. Niche ecommerce startups like beauty-focused Sociolla have also found success in adopting a similar strategy.See also: The next phase of SEA ecommerce: niche “super-verticals”By complementing physical retail with a digital platform, JD.id can generate more offline sales and attract more walk-in customers, Tung says. The firm plans to open and develop more O2O outlets in office and residential areas across Indonesia.Image credit: Timmy LoenIn Thailand, JD’s joint venture with local conglomerate Central Group also gives the Chinese firm “online assets” and a “massive retail footprint” across the country, says Sasin’s Towson. The professor adds that this partnership could be a catalyst for JD to rapidly expand its O2O retail in Thailand.On top of its network of offline retail outlets, JD’s logistics expertise also bolsters its O2O strategy.Unlike Alibaba’s hands-off approach to and its logistics arm Cainiao, JD is directly involved with fulfillment and order deliveries. In May, JD Logistics debuted on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.In Indonesia, the firm has distribution centers in every major island, says Leo Haryono, chief marketing officer at JD.id. He adds that the company’s delivery arm J-Express (not to be confused with J&T Express) also offers 24-hour delivery, covering 85% of areas nationwide and 95% of the Jakarta Metropolitan area.Meanwhile, both Shopee and Lazada have just started warming up to the idea of in-house logistics, as shown in this Tech in Asia’s analysis. In particular, Shopee still outsources the bulk of deliveries to third-party logistics providers.Just how effective JD.id’s O2O play is not clear yet. The company placed sixth among Indonesian ecommerce players in terms of average active users, according to App Annie. JD.id also trailed in ninth place in terms of visitor traffic in the first quarter of 2021.There could also be limits to how well JD can tap its strengths in logistics and offline retail. Scaling and replicating its logistics and offline retail footprint could be difficult, given Southeast Asia’s geographical constraints.JD’s advantages are also unwieldy in the early stages of expansion, cautions Towson. “The firm’s edge in quality control, cross-border ecommerce, and logistics are important in the long term,” he says. “But initially, it’s going to be all about consumer adoption and engagement.” And in Southeast Asia, that will require spending and innovating on the customer experience as well as training and onboarding the region’s merchants, who are still mostly offline.Still, JD isn’t without a few tricks up its sleeve. Its dominance in selling computer, communication, and consumer (3C) electronics could be a game-changer for its O2O play.“JD traditionally has been strong in this sector in China,” Towson observes. “If they pull off the same standard in Southeast Asia, they’re going to own that category.”More importantly, JD’s vast supply chain of high-quality Chinese merchants and manufacturers – which regional players can’t easily replicate – could also tip the scales in its favor.Going forwardIt’s likely that JD’s main thrust in Indonesia will be centered on O2O.JD.id’s Haryono says the firm will invest more in its supply chain. It’s also expanding its O2O efforts by developing JD Hubs, which refer to company-owned facilities in the Jakarta Metropolitan Area that offer self-pickup services.How far will that expansion go? Towson suggests that JD likely isn’t looking to wrap its tentacles into every Southeast Asian market. A targeted approach is “probably well-suited to their higher quality positioning,” he notes.It’s unclear as well whether JD will make more bets elsewhere in the region. One option is Vietnam: JD currently holds about 13% of Tiki, which is one of the country’s rare tech “soonicorns.”Still, some factors could derail JD’s renewed offensive in Southeast Asia.For one, its ecommerce competitors pack serious firepower. Sea Group’s Shopee spent US$6.6 billion growing its business between 2018 to 2020, and it boasted a war chest worth nearly US$13 billion in October. Similarly, Alibaba injected US$4.4 billion into Lazada during the same period.JD may also have to deal with super-app contenders like AirAsia and Grab, which also want to carve a niche for themselves in Southeast Asia’s ecommerce and logistics sectors.AirAsia reported that revenue for its delivery unit Teleport has recovered to pre-pandemic levels, and its newly launched air freight service may pose a challenge to JD’s edge in logistics. Grab’s partnership with Ninja Van, which began 2019, also places the Singapore-based super app directly in JD’s crosshairs.As part of its “new retail” strategy, close competitor Alibaba is also venturing deeper into the O2O space. In May, it co-led a US$400 million funding round into The CrownX, the retail subsidiary of Vietnamese conglomerate Masan Group. Alibaba has also led a US$100 million funding round into supermarket chain T11, which operates under a similar model to the Chinese tech titan’s Freshippo.To win, JD could take a leaf from its playbook for China, where the company rose to the top not being the first mover, but by being the most aggressive player instead.A few years ago, JD waged a series of price wars with competitors and traditional retailers in China that saw the firm’s annual sales soar from US$6.6 billion in 2012 to an estimated US$25.2 billion in 2015. Its 2020 net revenue stood at US$34.4 billion.Ultimately, there’s going to be a lot of space for more players in Southeast Asia, says Kung Fu Data’s Gardner. “I’m not sure JD needs to compete with other companies, and it’s likely they’ll still be able to carve a good 20 to 30% of the pie,” he says.
excerpt: As China’s JD.com ramps up its regional push, its first-party logistics play could be a gamechanger.
editor: Thu Huong Le, Terence Lee, and Eileen C. Ang

title: 1982 Ventures nets $12.5m in first close of seed fund
content: 1982 Ventures, a Singapore-based early-stage VC firm, announced the first close of its first seed-stage venture fund with US$12.5 million in committed capital. The company targets a total corpus of US$15 million for the fund.1982 Ventures co-founders and managing partners Scott Krivokopich (left) and Herston Elton Powers / Photo credit: 1982 Ventures1982 Ventures focuses on funding seed-stage fintech startups in Southeast Asia. The firm said its portfolio delivered a return of more than 3x, with investments in firms such as Indonesian banking player Brick, Vietnamese retail investment platform Infina, Vietnamese proptech firm Homebase, and Indonesian wage access platform Wagely.1982 Ventures recently joined funding rounds of personal finance app Pinaand buy-now, pay-later startup Fundiin.The VC firm was founded at the end of 2019 by Scott Krivokopich and Herston Elton Powers, both former executives of Southeast Asian fintech investor Tryb Group.1982 Ventures is eyeing investments in a total of 30 startups from the region, whose fintech market has an unrealized value of US$10 billion, according to a report.The firm said the fund’s core focus will be on startups in Indonesia, Vietnam, Singapore, and the Philippines, with the ability invest across the region, including Pakistan and Bangladesh if possible.“Seed stage fintech in Southeast Asia is a clear and once in a generation opportunity. Our focus and credibility with founders make us first money invested and the partner of choice for fintech entrepreneurs in the region,” said Powers, co-founder and managing partner of 1982 Ventures.
excerpt: The early-stage VC firm based in Singapore aims to invest in 30 fintech startups across Southeast Asia.
tags: ['1982 ventures', 'Fintech funding', 'fintech in southeast asia', 'seed fund', 'Singapore', 'southeast asia fintech', 'venture fund']

title: Ex‐Israel Defense execs’ firm raises $30m in series B money
content: Israel-based Cylus, a firm that provides cybersecurity to railway companies, has raised US$30 million in a series B financing round led by Ibex Investors, with participation from Vertex Growth Fund and Strides International Business, among others.Photo credit: CylusCylusOne, the Tel Aviv-based company’s flagship product, offers cybersecurity services for the railway industry, enabling real-time threat detection, advanced forensics and mitigation, and simplified security operations.The startup was founded in 2017 by Miki Shifman and Amir Levintal, both of whom have previously served in the Israel Defense Forces. They specialize in cybersecurity, machine learning, traffic management, signaling, and onboarding train systems.Cylus will use the fresh funds to fuel its growth in North America, as well as across Europe and the Asia Pacific.The fresh investment comes against the backdrop of an jump in the number of cyber attacks on railways and a growing demand for security solutions. The market size of the global railway cybersecurity industry is poised to hit U$10.2 billion by 2027.The latest round brings the company’s total funding to over US$57 million.As part of the deal, William Heinrich, former chief information security officer of Amtrak and BNSF Railway, and Mark Grant, former chief information security officer of CSX Transportation, will join Cylus’ advisory board.See also: 50 rising startups in IsraelOther investors in this round include:Magma Venture PartnersVertex Ventures IsraelZohar Zisapel, member of Cylus’ board, and Glenrock Israel
excerpt: Cylus’ flagship product offers cybersecurity services for the railway industry, enabling real-time threat detection and other protective features.

title: Indian BNPL firm bags $70m in series A money
content: India-based Uni, a fintech firm that provides buy now, pay later services, has raised US$70 million in a series A round led by General Catalyst and joined by Eight Roads Ventures, Elevation Capital, and other investors.The Uni team / Photo credit: UniUni aims to tap the growing need for credit services in India, where credit card penetration has remained relatively low. The company expects the BNPL market in India to be worth up to US$50 billion by 2026 – an exponential jump from the current market size of US$3 billion to US$3.5 billion, citing a RedSeer report.Founded in 2020 by Nitin Gupta, Prateek Jindal, and Laxmikant Vyas, Uni is aiming to hit monthly disbursals of 15 billion rupees (US$196 million) in the next year. Within six months of its official launch, the fintech firm’s flagship product – the Pay 1/3rd card – hit 1.75 billion rupees (US$22.9 million) in monthly disbursals.The fintech startup plans to utilize the fresh capital to scale up the team, launch new products, and invest in technology.See also: BNPL lights up India’s ecommerce sales this Diwali Other investors in this round include:Arbor VenturesLightspeed (existing investor)Accel (existing investor)Currency converted from Indian rupee to US dollar: US$1 = 76.07 rupees.
excerpt: Uni is looking to tap India’s booming BNPL market, which is estimated to be worth up to US$50 billion by 2026.
tags: ['Accel', 'asia fintech', 'BNPL', 'buy now pay later', 'Eight Road Ventures', 'Elevation Capital', 'funding brief', 'General Catalyst', 'India', 'Lightrock India', 'Uni']

title: 🇮🇳 Roundup: Apna to hire 400 people in next 6 months, and more
content: Startups including Uni, Juspay, Nestasia, MoEVing, Practically, and TagMango have collectively raised at least US$145.5 million today in disclosed funding from international and local investors.Here’s a snapshot of fundraising:Here’s some important tech news in India today:Tiger-backed Apna to double its team size in next six monthsThe Tiger Global-backed jobs-and-professional-networking firm will hire more than 400 employees across verticals in the next six months.Out of the total, 65% of the new hiring will focus on engineering, data science, and product teams. The company said it will recruit talent from renowned educational institutes in India, including the Indian Institute of Technology, Indian Institute of Management, and Indian School of Business.Apna, which became a unicorn in September this year, has more than 16 million users, over 150,000 employer partners, and operates in more than 40 cities across India. Since its inception, it has facilitated more than 18 million interviews.Fintech-focused VC firm raised US$18.3 million in final close of fundVaranium NexGen Fund plans to invest into 14 to 18 startups, out of which it has already invested in five startups and has made commitments to three more startups.The investors in the fund include veterans from the fintech domain, family offices, financial institutions, professionals, and entrepreneurs including former CEOs and CXOs of banks.It’s portfolio includes fintech firm for homebuyers Homecapital, insurtech platform Riskcovry, and fraud risk monitoring for payment firm Dronapay.Plum teams up with Razorpay RizeInsurtech startup Plum has partnered with Razorpay Rize, a launchpad for first-time entrepreneurs, to provide exclusive group health benefits to founders on the latter’s platform.Plum aims to cover more than 100,000 businesses and entrepreneurs with the new initiative. The startup noted that many early-stage entrepreneurs miss out on their existing health benefits when they leave their jobs and begin their entrepreneurial journey.All Razorpay Rize members will be eligible for benefits such as unlimited doctor consultations, wellness programs, annual dental and vision checkups, and more from Plum.Teachmint buys course-selling platformEdtech firm Teachmint has acquired Teachmore, a course-selling platform that allows teachers to sell content such as online courses, quizzes, and more in a cash-and-stock deal.Following the acquisition, Teachmore will continue to operate independently, but will also be integrated with Teachmint’s platform. The company said the integration will help build a course-selling suite and support the growing community of teachers on its platform.It is also Teachmint’s first acquisition since its US$78 million series B roundled by Rocketship.vc and Vulcan Capital. The company had then said its roadmap included acquisitions and partnerships with key players across the educational system.Pine Labs partners with AU Small Finance BankThe merchant commerce firm has teamed up with AU Small Finance Bank, a scheduled commercial bank, to allow the latter’s credit cardholders to avail equated monthly installment (EMI) offers at the point of sale at more than 200,000 merchants partnered with Pine Labs in India.The partnership is likely to benefit a large section of the underbanked population as 55% to 60% of AU’s customers are first-time credit cardholders, spread across India, including Tier 3 and Tier 4 cities.Pine Labs also highlighted that it’s also expanding its buy now, pay later services to more international markets. It recently partnered with Standard Chartered Malaysia to offer zero-interest installment purchase options to the bank’s customers.Bewakoof launches curated marketplaceThe direct-to-customer fashion brand said that the marketplace has already onboarded more than 150 brands, including Chumbak, Mad over print, Brown Mocha, Fugazee, and Peri Pai, among others.The firm aims to generate nearly US$65 million in brand sales from the marketplace in the next 12 months.The marketplace currently features sections such as fashion, innerwear, audio, beauty, and accessories. The company plans to add the home decor category in the financial year ending 2022.Tiger Global-backed Infra.Market may acquire electrical firmThe online procurement platform is reportedly in late-stage talks to buy electrical firm Halonix for up to US$100 million.Infra.Market, which turned into a unicorn earlier this year, had acquired construction-focused marketplace RDC Concrete for US$100 million in September.Halonix, bought by Hong Kong-based NewQuest Capital in 2016, manufactures a wide range of electrical appliances, including streetlights, LEDs, luminaires, and more.Follow the rest of our India coverage here.Currency converted from Indian rupee to US dollar: US$1 = 76.07 rupees.
excerpt: Edtech firm Teachmint acquires Teachmore, Pine Labs partners with AU Small Finance Bank, and other news.
tags: ['Apna', 'briefing', 'India', 'India Roundup', 'infra market', 'juspay', 'new briefing', 'Pine Labs', 'plum', 'practically', 'razorpay', 'Teachmint', 'Varanium NexGen Fund']

title: SoftBank leads $60m round of Indian payments firm
content: Juspay, an India-based payment gateway firm, banked US$60 million in a series C funding round led by SoftBank VisionFund 2, with participation from existing backers VEF and Wellington Management.Photo credit: JuspayThe startup offers a platform that gives merchants access to an end-to-end payment stack to help them achieve higher revenue at lower costs.Its suite includes Juspay Safe, a payment browser that simplifies authentication, and Express Checkout, a payments management platform with hundreds of payment options. The company said it currently processes 11 million transactions per day – one of the highest daily volumes in India.Juspay was founded by Vimal Kumar, the company’s CEO, and Ramanathan RV in 2012. Ramanathan left the company in October 2019 to co-found another fintech firm, Hyperface.Since its establishment, Juspay has onboarded clients such as Amazon, Flipkart, Cred, Swiggy, Tata, and Reliance Jio.See Also: A list of India’s unicorns and their early investors (Updated)The company said it will use the new funds to scale its payments business and other related products like credit both in India and globally.
excerpt: Juspay said it currently processes 11 million transactions per day – one of the highest daily rates in India.
tags: ['fintech', 'funding brief', 'India', 'juspay', 'payments', 'Softbank', 'Softbank Vision Fund 2', 'startups in india', 'vef', 'Wellington Management']

title: Indonesia launches fund for soonicorns
content: Indonesian President Jokowi officially launched the Merah Putih Fund, a venture capital fund that is backed by state-owned enterprises (SOEs).At the inauguration ceremony on Wednesday in Jakarta, Jokowi revealed that the Merah Putih Fund would focus on investing in soonicorns (firms soon to be unicorns).“We already have seven unicorns and there are lots of soonicorns which will continue to be encouraged to become unicorns and decacorns,” said President Jokowi.Indonesia president, Jokowi / Source: Cabinet secretariat of the republic of IndonesiaMandiri Capital, BRI Ventures, MDI Ventures, and Telkom Mitra Inovasi are the initial SOE investors backing the fund. Besides SOEs, the national private sector has also been invited by the president to join the Merah Putih Fund.Some reports suggest the launch of the Merah Putih Fund will take place on December 17, but Eddi Danusaputro, CEO of Mandiri Capital, confirmed it would be launched on December 15.In the first and second quarter of 2022, the Merah Putih Fund will aim to raise a total of US$300 million for investment in soonicorns.“We are not targeting how many startups will be funded. We are looking for quality,” said Danusaputro.Merah Putih Fund will focus on startups that already have a track record of fundraising. The fund’s investments will not be limited to certain business verticals, Danusaputro noted.Erick Thohir, Indonesia’s SOE minister, also stated that startups would have to meet several criteria to be funded by the Merah Putih Fund. An eligible company will have an Indonesian founder, be operating in the country, and have plans to go public in Indonesia.There are several Indonesian startups such as Ruangguru, SiCepat, Social Bella, GudangAda, and Kopi Kenangan that are predicted to soon become unicorns.
excerpt: “We have seven unicorns and there are lots of soonicorns, which will continue to be encouraged to become unicorns and decacorns,” said President Jokowi.
