title: Will Sea ride the Metaverse wave?
content: Sign up for the Daily Newsletter, sent exclusively to our Premium subscribers. We break down the big and messy topics of Asia’s tech and startup community. Get the newsletter in your inbox everyday with a Premium subscription.Hello reader,My grandmother is a straight-talking woman born in the pre-independent India of the 1930s. She delights in telling me stories of her past – about how she navigated an uncertain political landscape or how she is in awe of all this technological advancement.Her face lights up as she fondly recalls the first time she came across a radio set: It was a gift from her uncle and she remembers how she would sit with her family by the radio set for hours, listening to the news, vibing to music, and laughing over comic skits. How times change, right?By now, you’ve probably realized my grandmother is not really tech-savvy and hardly uses the internet. She still reacts with a child-like chuckle of wonder every time she gets a WhatsApp message. The prospect of explaining the metaverse to her ties my stomach in knots.On that note, today we probe whether Sea Group is ready to dip its toes into the metaverse. Also, if you are an entrepreneur looking for funding, fill in this form to get your company featured on our list of fundraising startups.Today we look at,Sea Group’s prospects in the metaverse worldZoomcar’s aggressive expansion through SEAOther newsy highlights such as Grab settling with ex-staffers in Vietnam and Good Glamm’s acquisition of MissMalini EntertainmentPremium summaryCarpe Diem: Seas the dayImage credit: Timmy LoenIf you look closely, you’ll notice that bits of the metaverse are already around us. As we stand on the cusp of a technological revolution, it is important to realize that the metaverse will not spring to life all of a sudden. For the metaverse to well and truly take off, it’s crucial that companies collaborate with each other. That’s why Tech in Asia took a deep dive at whether Sea Group has the necessary tools to become a key player in this space.Leaving a trail in the dark: Does Sea have any plans for the metaverse? It hasn’t given any indication of this yet. However, the firm’s recent actions provide some food for thought. Sea has already achieved a form of interoperability – a key concept that some say is critical in the metaverse – by ensuring players of its gaming titles, Free Fire and Free Fire Max, can play together seamlessly.Advantage, Sea Group: Sea’s core businesses, Shopee and SeaMoney, are focused on ecommerce and payments, respectively, which are important building blocks of the metaverse. Shopee, which started out selling physical goods, is already branching out in various directions, offering digital vouchers, food delivery, and more. Adding virtual items to the mix wouldn’t be far-fetched.All clues point toward the metaverse: Sea Capital, the company’s investment arm, has made a couple of relevant investments in the crypto assets space. One of them is Forte, which helps gaming publishers incorporate blockchain technology into their games. This allows non-fungible tokens (NFTs), which are crucial to the metaverse, to be minted and sold within games, allowing players to freely trade goods and services with each other.Read more: Sea could be massive in the metaverse if it wants to beStartup spotlightVroom Vroom! Accelerating through SEAPeople standing next to a car rented from Zoomcar / Photo credit: ZoomcarWithin a fortnight of announcing plans to launch in Vietnam, Zoomcar, an India-based car rental startup, is already driving its services into the Philippines. This launch is part of its aggressive expansion plan to capture a sizable chunk of the Southeast Asian markets. Zoomcar will invest US$25 million over the next 12 months to fuel its expansion in the Philippines.Local businesses key to growth: Zoomcar aims to have 1,000 cars available for rent in the Philippines by January 2022. The figure will likely touch 20,000 cars by the end of next year. In order to reach those figures, the company will partner with individual car owners and SMEs with multiple vehicles.Branching out from the capital: Zoomcar will start its Philippine operations in Metro Manila, and it is set to launch in Cebu and Davao next year. The company plans to cover 20 cities in the archipelago by 2023.An IPO to keep in mind: The firm’s aggressive expansion into other countries comes ahead of the company’s plans to go public in the US by around August 2022. Zoomcar is looking to raise a “nine-digit million number” in US dollars from its listing.PodcastDark stores – more widely known as microdistribution hubs – have been gaining prominence in India and Southeast Asia, with grocery delivery startups like Dropezy and Zepto raising millions of dollars in funding and setting up hundreds of centers across the region.The future of this segment is brighter than its name suggests: By 2025, the size of India’s consumables market is projected to hit roughly US$1 trillion, while Southeast Asia’s online grocery market is expected to reach US$11.9 billion – which opens up a prime opportunity for operators of dark stores.In this episode of Deep Dive, Tech in Asia’s Nikita Puri discusses the ins and outs of this rising phenomenon, its key players, and how dark stores can change the way we buy groceries – or anything else for that matter.Listen here: Spotify | Apple PodcastsQuick bytes1️⃣ The dust settlesGrab said it reached a settlement with most ex-staffers in Vietnam following a dispute over their shares in the company. Additionally, Tech in Asia understands that Grab is working to register an updated employee stock ownership plan program with the State Bank of Vietnam.2️⃣ Adding glitz to the GlammGood Glamm Group, an India-based content-to-commerce company, has acquired MissMalini Entertainment, a local celebrity media and influencer talent management network. The deal will provide Good Glamm with access to a network of influencers, celebrities, and market know-how, boosting its entertainment, celebrity, and influencer marketing vertical.3️⃣ Not so boring anymoreHong Kong-based unicorn Animoca Brands has partnered with Bored Ape Yacht Club (BAYC) to develop and publish a blockchain game utilizing the latter’s popular Bored Ape NFTs. The gaming firm and BAYC creators Yuga Labs expect to release the new game in the second quarter of 2022.4️⃣ Scurry for the CrownXThe CrownX, a retail platform of Vietnamese consumer group Masan Group, has raised a US$350 million investment from TPG, a private equity firm; Platinum Orchid, a unit of Abu Dhabi Investment Authority; and SeaTown Master Fund, which is owned by an indirect subsidiary of Temasek Holdings. The group says this is the final fundraise of The CrownX, whose valuation shot up to US$8.2 billion.5️⃣ Plus points for filteringNephroPlus, an India-based chain of dialysis centers, closed a US$24 million series E round to pursue growth opportunities across India and certain international markets. IIFL Asset Management led the round, while existing investors InvestCorp and Bessemer Venture Partners also returned to the table.6️⃣ Invest in healthLemonilo, an Indonesian brand that produces healthy consumer goods, has raised US$36 million in a series C funding round led by Sofina, with Sequoia Capital India participating. Lemonilo has launched more than 40 types of products, from instant noodles and snacks to spices.
excerpt: We take a look at Sea Group’s potential in the metaverse space and Zoomcar’s rapid expansion across SEA

title: We minted and sold an NFT for $1,100. Here’s what we learned
content: Our announcement that we were going to sell an NFT artwork generated a bit of buzz, though it wasn’t all positive.One person thought it was “lame AF,” while a couple of others thought it goes against our green ethos (more on this in a bit).Still, we were having too much fun to care.We changed the theme of the artwork at the last minute – after realizing that Grab’s IPO was just around the corner – and then we worked late into the night and over weekends to get everything ready. (Apparently, the “996” work culture is common in the crypto world, I later learned.)Image credit: Timmy LoenAfter the auction launched, I nervously refreshed the page one too many times while on a staycation to see how it was going.10/10 I will do this again.Who wonIn the end, after getting three bids, we sold the piece for US$1,100. And the winner was… anonymous.This person, it seems, used a dormant wallet to buy this artwork and clearly knows his or her way around crypto.We sent out a blast to our mailing list asking the buyer to come forth, but alas, maybe the person had buyer’s remorse already. (We’re still waiting.)Still, congrats to anon for owning a piece of history. We hope you’ve found the purchase worthwhile.Where did the proceeds go?We found out that Ethereum gas fees (essentially transaction fees) took a huge bite out of our proceeds, leaving us with US$731. Still, that’s not too bad. We used all the money to buy carbon credits. We also topped upanother US$7,204.51 to purchase a total of 1,000 carbon credits.This makes us carbon neutral for the year 2022. It also offset the legacy carbon emissions we put into the atmosphere during our founding years in 2011, 2012, and 2013. Thank you Cool Effect for making this possible. You can check out our carbon reduction and offset progress here.What did we learn?Running this experiment certainly got us thinking a lot more about NFTs – what its implications are for the creator economy, what it could mean for Tech in Asia, and so on. We do believe this won’t be the last NFT we’ll create.Finding a new foundationFor this auction, we used Foundation, a sleek NFT marketplace built on top of Ethereum that is suited for edition-of-one digital artworks.What wasn’t sleek about it was the gas fees for minting and listing the NFT, which was surely a deterrent to potential buyers.When we auction our next NFT, we’ll check out other marketplaces that are much more friendly on the wallet – and the earth.Bad for the planet?Bitcoin and Ethereum have been criticized for consuming too much electricity.See also: Why China’s crypto exodus is a boon for green bitcoin miningHowever, we believe that this argument is outdated.First, Ethereum will soon move to a proof-of-stake model, a method of verifying blockchain transactions that doesn’t require intense computations and, therefore, consumes far less power.Second, a number of NFT marketplaces support “layer 2 networks” as well as alternative blockchain networks that are much less energy-intensive.OpenSea, for example, supports Polygon, a layer 2 network built on top of Ethereum. SolSea, meanwhile, is built on Solana, a proof-of-stake Ethereum competitor.We believe minting and selling NFTs on marketplaces like these is the way to go.Tactical lessonsOn the execution side, we picked up a few things, too.We’d definitely want to give ourselves more time in the next go-round to create a stunning piece of work.NFT art pieces are fundamentally different from PFP (profile pic) NFTs. Both are meant to be eye candy, but while PFP NFTs are essentially expensive Twitter profile pictures, NFT art pieces are something you’d want to print and frame up on your wall or display on a large screen.We might also play around with the auction’s timing (weekdays instead of weekends) and its length (is 24 hours the right amount of time?).We’ll also find ways to better remind interested parties about our auction, such as allowing them to set up calendar reminders.All in all, we’re happy we did this. I can’t speak for the others, but I came away from this no less enthusiastic about NFTs (though I think there are way too many Bored Ape Yacht Club copycats around).In my view, NFTs have the potential to:Easily verify ownership and provenance, which prevents art scams like thisImbue utility into ownershipImprove liquidity of the content marketSeamlessly reward content creators with a cut of secondary salesWhile NFTs have been criticized for being worthless because the underlying asset can be easily copy-pasted, that argument was so yesterday.After all, the abundance of forgeries has not stopped an original Kooning or Rothko from fetching millions of dollars in the art market. Owning counterfeits defeats the purpose of owning an art piece: bragging rights.In the meantime, we’re happy to join the ranks of this group of pioneers – modest as our results may be.Want to be the first to know about our next NFT artwork? Drop your email address in the form below.
excerpt: One person thought it was “lame AF,” but we were having too much fun to care.

title: Foodpanda, HungryPanda brawl over trademark dispute
content: Foodpanda, one of the largest food delivery startups in Asia outside of China, is in a legal spat with HungryPanda SG over an alleged trademark infringement, The Business Times reported.HungryPanda SG filed for its logo trademark in Singapore on August 2020, while Foodpanda filed for its own trademark in August 2012. Recently, Foodpanda filed an opposition against HungryPanda’s application.Foodpanda said that HungryPanda’s trademarks are visually similar to that of its own. The former added that the panda visual is distinct for Foodpanda because of heavy advertising and its usage over a long period.According to the legal filings, consumers may mistake HungryPanda’s services and products for that of Foodpanda’s.See also: Foodpanda grows revenue by 2.5x, but profit is still some distance awayFoodpanda, which was acquired by Germany-based Delivery Hero in 2016, has become a prized possession for its parent firm, as it was one of its main drivers of revenue in the third quarter of 2021.
excerpt: Foodpanda said the panda visual is distinct for the company due to heavy advertising and its usage over a long period.
editor: Miguel Cordon and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: The brewing battle between Amazon and Visa
content: Welcome to The Top Up! Delivered every Wednesday via email and through the Tech in Asia website, this free newsletter breaks down the biggest stories and trends in fintech. If you’re not a subscriber, get access by registering here.Hello there,This is the last issue of The Top Up for 2021, as we’re pausing for our year-end break starting next week.With 2022 around the corner, I’ll be treating myself by purchasing a yoga mat and a skipping rope from Amazon – the items are already sitting in my cart.In all likelihood, I’ll be making the transaction via UPI (unified payments interface), a payment system developed by the National Payments Corporation of India. It’s my choice for online transactions over debit or credit cards whenever I’m in the country. In fact, since I got my credit card three years ago, I have never used it.With a boom in UPI payments in India, credit card transactions are on the decline, and I assumed that this was true in the rest of the world, too.But that’s apparently not the case. Cards continue to be the dominant payment method for many others globally, and stakeholders including merchants, card companies, and banks are fighting it out to make the most of it.Financial services firms like Mastercard and Visa set the fees that retailers must pay for processing card payments, which they revise from time to time. While small businesses can do little to negotiate this fee, big players like Amazon can easily turn the tables on card companies.In this week’s big story, my colleague Melissa Goh breaks down Amazon’s upcoming ban on Visa credit cards in the UK, signaling that the power balance is shifting between merchants, banks, and payment firms.This could also be an opportunity for other payment providers such as digital wallets and buy now, pay later players to gain more traction. As for Visa, it still has until early next year to resolve its issues with Amazon. Read on to know more.This week, analyst Simon Huang also breaks down Brazil-based Nubank’s success in Latin America following its stock debut on the New York Stock Exchange and what Southeast Asia’s digital banks can learn from it.A Happy New Year to all of you in advance! We’ll see you again in January.— SamreenTHE BIG STORYThe Amazon-Visa standoff: What’s the endgame?Image credit: Timmy LoenAmazon’s ban on Visa credit cards in the UK is a sign that the power balance between merchants, banks, and payment firms is shifting.THE HOT TAKEEmulating Nubank’s success in Southeast AsiaHere’s what happened:Nubank, the Brazil-based digital bank, had a successful stock market debut on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE).Nubank grew by prioritizing user experience and focusing on markets that have large unbanked populations and inefficient legacy banks.In Southeast Asia, Indonesia is the most attractive market for digital banks, but it also has no restrictions on the number of players that can operate in the country.Here’s what it means:Nubank made its stock market debut last Thursday (December 9) on the NYSE.Initial investor interest has been ecstatic: Shares opened 25% over the offer price, giving the company a market value of almost US$52 billion.What lessons can Southeast Asia’s fledgling digital banks learn from Nubank?First, it’s important to serve a large market with low banking penetration. Currently, Nubank has a presence in three Latin American markets – Brazil, Mexico, and Colombia. Combined, these countries have a total population of 393 million people, with 134 million unbanked adults in 2017, according to the World Bank.A large population is a prerequisite to achieve the scale necessary to build a sustainable digital banking business in the long term. This was the basis for Nubank’s 12x customer base increase – from 4 million in the first quarter of 2018 to 48 million as of the third quarter of 2021.Aspiring digital banks in Southeast Asia cannot confine themselves to smaller, well-banked markets like Singapore and Malaysia. Instead, they must find ways to reach out to consumers in places like Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam.Second, it helps to have competitors that have large workforces, legacy systems, and existing bank branches, which are costly to operate.For example, Brazil has 17.9 commercial bank branches per 100,000 adults, which is above the global average of 14.1. The costs involved in maintaining these physical locations means incumbents spend more serving each active customer – approximately US$15.70 in Brazil. With no physical bank branches, Nubank’s equivalent costs are 85% lower.Again, this points to Indonesia as an attractive market for disruption. The archipelago has the highest number of commercial bank branches per 100,000 adults in Southeast Asia, at 15.2. Thailand has 11.2 bank branches per 100,000 adults, making it the runner-up.Third, it’s crucial for digital banks to prioritize user experience. Nubank started out with a single product (credit cards), but it achieved a net promoter score (NPS) of over 90. The average for banks globally is only 32.This resulted in strong word-of-mouth recommendations, which reduced Nubank’s customer acquisition costs to US$5 per customer and cemented its position as the primary bank for over 50% of its active customers who have been with the bank for more than 12 months.In comparison, the market leaders in Indonesia and Thailand currently have an NPS of 45 and 39, respectively.As a market for digital banks, Indonesia would appear to have a lot going for it. However, unlike in Singapore and Malaysia, which limit the number of their digital banks, Indonesia’s Financial Services Authority does not have a cap on the number of digital banks that can operate in the country, as long as certain minimum requirements are met.This will undoubtedly lead to more intense competition in Indonesia and may make a pan-Southeast Asian strategy more likely for many players. But it also introduces complexity, as banks have to deal with different regulators, languages, and cultures.No one said the road to success would be easy.— SimonNEWS YOU SHOULD KNOWCheck out Tech in Asia’s coverage of the fintech scene here.1️⃣ Sequoia co-leads $48m round of Indonesian fintech startup: Flip offers financial services including interbank transfers, overseas transfers, e-wallet top-ups, and salary transfers to employees of small and medium-sized businesses.2️⃣ India’s banking revolution has started without the banks: The country’s licensing policy for financial institutions is past its sell-by date. Innovative solutions are out there but require regulation.3️⃣ Israeli fintech firm Tipalti soars to over $8b valuation after $270m investment: A developer of payments and compliance solutions, Tipalti’s client list includes Amazon, Twitter, and Vimeo.FYI1️⃣ Evolve or perish may be the only mantra for Indian fintech: Fintech companies would have to adopt an open banking platform to serve customers in the fast-changing industry, says a Forbes report.That’s it for this edition – we hope you liked it! Do also check out previous issues of the newsletter here.Not your cup of tea? You can unsubscribe from this newsletter by going to your “edit profile” page and choosing that option in our preference center.In the meantime, if you have any feedback or ideas, feel free to get in touch with Terence, our editor-in-chief, at terence@techinasia.com.See you next week!
excerpt: The Top Up is Tech in Asia’s free newsletter that breaks down the biggest stories and trends in fintech.
editor: Terence Lee, Melissa Goh, and Jaclyn Tiu
tags: ['Amazon', 'digital bank', 'digital banking', 'fintech', 'Flip', 'interchange fees', 'mastercard', 'Nubank', 'payment-gateway', 'payments processing', 'Southeast Asia', 'The Top Up', 'Tipalti', 'visa']

title: Byju’s unit eyes 1 million paid users as it gears for acquisitions next year
content: Great Learning, a Singapore-based professional and higher education startup that is part of the Byju’s group, is eyeing 1 million paid users on its platform in the next five years.(From left) Great Learning co-founders Hari Krishnan Nair, Mohan Lakhamraju, and Arjun Nair / Photo credit: Great LearningIt currently has a user base of 3 million, of which 70,000 are paid subscribers, Great Learning co-founder and CEO Mohan Lakhamraju told Tech in Asia.The company is looking to double the number of courses that it offers from 60 to 120 within the next year in order to cater to a wider group of audience. It offers higher education courses in popular domains such as cloud computing, cybersecurity, and management.Great Learning has a presence in over 170 countries, with 50% of its revenue coming from India.Team Byju’sIn July, Great Learning was acquired by edtech behemoth Byju’s for US$600 million in a cash, stock, and earnout deal. It also committed US$400 million in investment to accelerate Great Learning’s growth.“We have access to a lot more resources and capital now, which will allow us to pursue our inorganic growth plans,” said Lakhamraju, who previously headed Tiger Global’s India team. Great Learning will be making multiple acquisitions in the higher education and upskilling segments by the end of next year, with a few to be wrapped up this month.It was earlier reported that Byju’s had borrowed US$1.2 billion in debt for its future acquisitions.Interestingly, Great Learning, which had been profitable for the past five years, will miss out the break-even train this year because of its multiple investments in the pipeline to expand its portfolio. Lakhamraju said it will take the startup almost two to three years to bounce back to profitability.See also: Byju’s aims to be profitable by FYE 2022 despite acquisition spreeSEA growth plansGreat Learning will be ramping up its presence in Southeast Asia in the coming year. The company has already formed a dedicated team to focus on its growth in the region.“We will be bringing all our courses that we offered in India and the US to Southeast Asia,” said Lakhamraju.
excerpt: Great Learning will be making multiple acquisitions in the higher education and upskilling segments by the end of next year.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: Uber plans to sell its stake in Didi
content: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi has said that the company is planning to sell its stake in Chinese ride-hailing company Didi, reported Reuters.The US-based ride-hailing firm exited China in 2016 after it failed to make a breakthrough in the market and encountered fierce competition from Didi. Eventually, Uber sold its China operations to its local competitor in exchange for a stake.Khosrowshahi also shared his sentiment on the Chinese market, saying that it has a “difficult environment with very little transparency.”Uber recently reported profitability on an adjusted EBITDA (earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortization) basis for the first time since its launch over a decade ago. The company, however, suffered from a drop in the value of its Didi stake.Didi itself is facing scrutiny from local regulators over its data protection policies. Earlier this month, the Chinese ride-hailing firm announced that it would be delisting from the New York Stock Exchange.See also: Grab shares may drop further as more stocks flood the market
excerpt: Uber CEO Dara Khosrowshahi also shared his sentiment on the Chinese market, saying that it has a “difficult environment with very little transparency.”

title: Ex-Grab execs create pill to cure hangovers in Asia
content: The effects of a hangover appear quite early in Kingsley Amis’ Lucky Jim. “Novelists go into the subject more deeply and extensively, but tend to straddle the target, either polishing off the hero’s hangover in a few sentences or so to speak, making it the whole of the novel,” the author said a couple of years ago.Roy Ang, a former senior Grab executive who always loved a drink or two, is all too familiar with the effects of a hangover. A couple of drinks while closing deals and networking came within territory for him.But the issue was staying clear and productive the next day. He sought for hangover cures in the region, but none were truly effective. He turned toward US-based products, but only a few were able to work their magic well.In a bid to address hangovers, Ang, along with another former Grab executiveMinghao Teoh, launched Bounceback to help Asian white-collar professionals get back up on their feet after a late night of drinking.Photo credit: BouncebackLaunched in September, the Singapore-based firm’s anti-hangover pill is made of natural substances, with Dihydromyricetin (DHM) as its “hero ingredient.” Derived from the Japanese raisin tree, DHM helps metabolize alcohol faster by decreasing blood alcohol concentration and promoting alcohol clearance.The pill is made of 22 vitamins, antioxidants, and herbal extracts, which replenish the depleted nutrients caused by drinking. It is currently priced at S$49.90 (US$36.43) in Singapore and 109 ringgit (US$25.80) in Malaysia.While the product is available in Singapore, a pilot test is currently underway in Malaysia. The company aims to launch its product in 10 markets by the end of 2022.Investors take a shotIn September, Bounceback raised an undisclosed sum in a seed round from investors including SparkLabs Ventures, Farquhar Ventures, Paragon Capital, and Bonjour Holdings.(From left:) Bounceback founders Roy Ang and Minghao Teoh/Photo credit: BouncebackThe company is looking to raise another US$3 million in its pre-series A round by January 2022. It will use the funds to get approvals from various health regulators, complete its compliance process, and build its inventory.Bounceback will also use the new capital to ramp up hiring in its firm to a total of 25 employees. The company currently has eight full-time employees.Workday blues“White-collar workers are often subject to instances of drinking as they interact with people outside of a professional setting,” said Ang. Research also backs Ang’s statement: Regular drinkers make 10% to 14% more money than those who do not drink.Photo credit: lightfieldstudios / 123RFHowever, their recoveries after a late night drinking comes at a cost to companies and economies. For example, in Australia, sick days taken in the last two weeks of the year cost up to A$2 billion (US$1.6 billion) in lost productivity, with nearly 10% of employees opting for up to three sick days off before going back to work.Southeast Asia has witnessed a 34% increase in the consumption of alcohol between 2010 and 2017, driven by growing demand among countries in the low- and middle-income categories. Additionally, road traffic deaths due to alcohol consumption was among the top concerns in all countries and territories in the Asia-Pacific region in 2016.Lessons from Grab“Anthony [Tan, group CEO and co-founder of Grab] has a clear direction in what he wants to do. He has a strong mission-driven approach toward customer safety,” said Ang. He added that the Grab experience helps young professionals get a chance to learn a spectrum of skill sets.Photo montage by Tech in AsiaGrab has pushed companies to build communities similar to that of its own, which includes drivers and merchant partners, Ang said. Bounceback has also adopted this approach by distributing its pills at concerts anchored by local disc jockeys, instead of selling them through traditional pharmacies.Bounceback has also laid adequate emphasis on the design and layout of its product, which is in line with Grab’s strategy to create a strong brand.Photo credit: Bounceback“When a driver performs well, Grab gives them workshops on financial literacy and teaches them to manage their financial goals better,” Ang said. During his stint at Grab, he helped the company launch programs for drivers including investment savings and loan-related facilities.See also: Grab’s financial health in 8 chartsAng also noted that Tan believes in giving constructive feedback to his employees regarding the execution of plans and broader strategies. “He is always involved in ground-level work and talks to all the stakeholders.”Currency converted from Singapore dollar, Malaysian ringgit, and Australian dollar to US dollar: US$1 = S$1.37; US$1 = 4.23 ringgit; US$1= A$1.41.
excerpt: While the product is available in Singapore, a pilot test is currently underway in Malaysia. The company will launch its product in 10 markets by 2022.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: Women-only social media startup buys SG femtech firm
content: Eve World, a Singapore-based social platform for women, has acquired femtech firm Femcy for an undisclosed sum.Following the acquisition, Femcy founder Nandhini Gopal will join the Eve World team and spearhead the health and hygiene section of the upcoming platform.Photo credit: Eve WorldFemcy, which offers personalized menstrual wellness solutions, will continue to operate as a stand-alone brand, but it will be fully integrated into Eve World following the beta launch of the latter’s platform.Founded in 2019, Femcy offers a digital solutions platform for Asian women to improve their menstrual health.“The marketing power, intellect, and outreach of Eve World will help reach the Femcy offering to a larger discerning audience base, for whom menstrual issues are often treated by self-experimentation, inherited knowledge, and unverified tips from their support network,” Gopal said in a statement.Meanwhile, Eve World was founded earlier this year, and it aspires to be a safe space where women can freely express themselves. The platform, which is scheduled for a public launch by the end of the first quarter of 2022, will feature multi-format content and communities around women-centric issues, along with elements like social commerce, ecommerce, and brand stores. The app will be accessible from anywhere in the world.The platform will also have a layer of Web 3.0, allowing users to earn rewards from content creation, engagement, and curation, among other activities. These rewards will be available in the form of virtual tokens that can be used for purchasing in-app services and items. The company is also considering a feature that would let users exchange their tokens for real cash.While this feature will be available upon the platform’s launch, the company told Tech in Asia that it has not yet finalized the blockchain technology it will use. It has also not yet decided on whether it will use a crypto token due to uncertainties around cryptocurrencies and government policies.This is a similar model used by Philippine social media platform Lyka, which rewards users with GEMS (gift cards in electronic mode) that can be used to buy real-life goods and services – ranging from basic needs to luxury automobiles – within the Lyka ecosystem.See also: How social media app Lyka took the Philippines by stormFor privacy, Eve World says that it will have a safe onboarding process, including two-factor authentication and facial recognition.The Eve World platform is currently in its alpha stage, and it is being tested with a few thousand users, the company’s co-founder and CEO Tarun Katial told Tech in Asia.Katial comes with two decades of experience in the Indian media industry. He previously served as CEO of Zee5, an over-the-top platform. His former Zee5 colleagues Aparna Acharekar and Rajneel Kumar are also co-founders of Eve World.Eve World CEO Tarun Katial / Photo credit: Eve World“The garb of anonymity at the internet as a space [for women] has gotten worse than the street. Women desperately needed freedom to be able to express themselves, and create and discover content around issues that are important to them,” Katial said.He also hopes that in the future, Eve World will transition into a super app for women.Even though its platform is still months away from its public launch, Eve World has already raised money from Jungle Ventures in a pre-seed round in October. The company is also planning to raise seed money from the same VC firm as well as from other investors. However, Katial declined to divulge any more details about the upcoming fundraise.See also: Where will the new age of social media bring us?The company is also looking to increase its headcount to a three-digit figure over the next 18 months. Eve World currently has about 25 members spread across Taiwan, Singapore, India, Ukraine, and the Middle East. Katial added that the firm will hire fresh talent for verticals such as product development, technology, and content.Correction (December 15, 3:26 p.m SGT): The article has been corrected after Eve World clarified it is a Singapore-based firm.
excerpt: Singapore-based Eve World, which will launch its social platform next year, is also planning to raise a seed round from Jungle Ventures and other investors.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['blockchain', 'Eve World', 'Femcy', 'India', 'Jungle Ventures', 'Social Commerce', 'Social network', 'web3', 'women-only social media']

title: Grab to buy Malaysian grocery major
content: Southeast Asian super app Grab has signed an agreement to acquire Jaya Grocer, a Malaysia-based online and offline grocery firm, for an undisclosed sum.GrabSupermarket in Malaysia / Photo credit: GrabThe Singapore-headquartered tech giant has agreed to buy all the ordinary shares and 75% of the preference shares of Jaya Grocer, according to Grab’s filing on Nasdaq.Grab also has the option to buy up the remaining 25% of the grocery firm’s preference shares after closing the deal. The super app also said that it will partner with a Malaysia-based investor, which will own 50% of the voting shares in Jaya Grocer, to comply with the country’s regulations.The retail grocery store started back in December 2007 and has since grown to run 40 stores across Peninsular Malaysia, according to Grab. Most of these locations are in the Klang Valley area, an urban conglomeration centered in Kuala Lumpur.See also: Grab’s financial health in 8 charts“Following closing, Jaya Grocer is expected to become a subsidiary of Grab Holdings and its financial results will be consolidated by Grab Holdings,” the filing read. The deal is projected to close in the first quarter of 2022.
excerpt: Jaya Grocer is expected to become a subsidiary of Grab Holdings after the deal, which is projected to close in the first quarter of 2022.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: 3 steps to starting a DeFi protocol
content: What are the skills that one should seek when putting together a decentralized finance (DeFi) protocol team? And what are some problems that tend to get overlooked?Mike Phulsuksombati, CEO and co-founder of cross-chain DeFi dashboard Ape Board, shares his insights on starting a DeFi protocol.Ape Board is a DeFi portfolio aggregation dashboard that allows investors to view their investment portfolios, supporting over 100 protocols and covering 10 major chains.Learn more about Ape Board on its website.This content was produced by Tech in Asia Studios, which connects brands with Asia’s tech community. Learn more about partnering with Tech in Asia Studios.
excerpt: Mike Phulsuksombati, CEO and co-founder of Ape Board, talks about what people tend to overlook when starting a DeFi protocol.

title: Grab shares to surge over 80% to $12.5 by 2022 end, forecasts JP Morgan
content: Grab‘s first few days of public life haven’t been the easiest, with its shares ending last week at US$7.12 apiece, which is roughly a 45.5% discount to its opening price on December 2. Tech in Asia also recently reported that the Singapore giant’s shares may slump further in the first half of 2022 as more stock is released to the public.However, there may be a bright light at the end of the tunnel for Grab to drive through in 2022.Image credit: Tech in AsiaSee also: Grab shares may drop further as more stocks flood the marketGrab’s attractionJP Morgan has recently given the Southeast Asian super app an overweight rating when it initiated coverage on the stock. This is generally a recommendation to buy Grab’s stock, with the expectation of strong future performance.The investment bank attributes this rating, in part, to Grab’s massive presence in Southeast Asia. “In our view, Grab’s super-app ecosystem gives it a structural competitive advantage over peers with fewer services and limited geographical presence,” the JP Morgan report read.Starting out as a with ride-hailing service, Grab has since entered fintech, logistics, and food delivery, among a number of other spaces. It also recently secured licenses for digital banking in Singapore and Malaysia. This makes Grab one of the most active startups in Southeast Asia in terms of the number of verticals it operates in.According to JP Morgan, its wide regional net allows Grab to hold on to customers longer, with its one-year retention numbers climbing as consumers use more of its services.Consumers may also step up their in-app spending as they continue to use the company’s services. According to the report, users of the super app spent roughly 3.6x more in 2020 than they did when they first set up their accounts in 2016.See also: Grab’s position in SEA’s startup landscapeNirgunan Tiruchelvam, the head of Tellimer’s consumer sector equity research, agrees with the analysis. He said in his recent report that Grab’s potential as a super app has yet to be fully reached.Tiruchelvam has recently initiated coverage on Grab with a “buy” rating and a target price of US$13 by the end of 2022, while JP Morgan pegged it at US$12.5.More to come from mobilityAnother point the two reports agree on is the mobility segment could be a catalyst that drives a recovery in Grab’s share prices.In its coverage, JP Morgan said that the segment could get over US$1 billion in annual cash flows as movement restrictions ease and economies reopen.The financial services firm expects the mobility arm to rake in US$683 million in revenue for Grab by the end of next year and reach almost US$1.5 billion by the end of 2024. Meanwhile, Tiruchelvam expects Grab’s gross merchandise value from the delivery segment to clock a compound annual growth rate of 32% from 2020 through 2024.JP Morgan also sees the delivery segment – which recently became the company’s biggest cash cow – bringing in over US$1 billion in revenue for Grab by the end of 2024.See also: Grab’s financial health in 8 chartsIn its most recent quarterly financial report, Grab saw its revenues from deliveries see a 58% year-on-year growth, while its mobility business saw a further 26% decline from last year.However, Shifara Samsudeen, part of LightStream Research’s team in Sri Lanka, previously told Tech in Asiathat while deliveries have helped Grab greatly in offsetting a slump in its mobility business, the GrabMart and GrabSupermarket services have recently been facing heightened competition from companies such as GoTo and Sea’s ShopeeFood.See also: Examining Grab’s incentive-fueled growth“Moreover, we think with resurgence of Covid cases and emergence of Omicron variants, it will be unlikely for Grab to pursue overseas expansion (for deliveries) anytime soon,” Samsudeen added. “So, if Grab’s mobility segment could make a meaningful recovery over the next couple of quarters, it will be one key catalyst for Grab’s future share price performance.”
excerpt: Grab’s market price is expected to be volatile in the first half of 2022, but analysts see a smoother road ahead for the Singapore giant.

title: This deck raised $9m for ex-BBC strategist’s news audio startup
content: ﻿ ABOUTCurio offers a curated library of journalism in the form of audio, giving listeners their daily fix of news and analyses.The UK-based company was founded in 2016 by Govind Balakrishnan, who previously worked for the BBC as a strategist, and Srikant Chakravarti, a former solicitor in London.Curio includes content from the likes of The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, Financial Times, Wired, MIT Technology Review, and Aeon. The audio stories on the platform can be filtered according to new stories, most played, categories, and publications. Listeners can also discover new tracks on playlists curated bi-weekly by the Curio editorial team.The startup used this pitch deck for its series A round, and it said that it would use the funds to expand into new markets including India, Australia, and South Africa.Fundraising journey2018: US$2 million in seed funding from Cherry, 500 Global (formerly 500 Startups), and undisclosed private angel investors2020: US$9 million from a series A round led by Earlybird, with participation from Draper Esprit, Cherry Ventures, and Horizons VenturesHow is the deck compelling?The pitch deck is crisp since it mostly contains images and doesn’t include too many words.The deck begins with the background story of why Curio was developed and introduces the service that the company provides.On the business side, it shows the month-on-month revenue that Curio makes and how it performs compared to traditional news websites.SOURCEDeck: Failory
excerpt: Curio includes content from the likes of The Wall Street Journal, The Washington Post, and Financial Times.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: The Amazon-Visa stand-off: What’s the endgame?
content: In the tussle between retailers and all-powerful payment networks, who stands to lose the most?In November, Amazon took a swipe at Visa by imposing a ban. The payment giant’s UK-issued credit cards won’t be accepted on the ecommerce juggernaut’s local platform (amazon.co.uk) starting January 19, 2022, as it aims to encourage consumers to use better, lower-cost payment methods.Photo credit: 123rf.comThe move is the latest escalation of a years-long sticking point between merchants, payment networks, and banks. It comes after Visa raised fees for cross-border credit and debit card transactions between the UK and European Union. Amazon, however, said the ban was not about any one rule or fee, and that high costs of payment acceptance are a global problem that isn’t exclusive to the UK.“The cost of accepting card payments continues to be an obstacle for businesses striving to provide the best prices for customers. These costs should be going down over time with technological advancements, but instead they continue to stay high or even rise,” an Amazon spokesperson tells Tech in Asia.The fees in contention are known in the industry as interchange fees, or what a customer’s card-issuing bank charges a retailer for every transaction. This is just one – though significant – component of the merchant discount rate (MDR), which refers to the fees shouldered by retailers for processing card payments.Image credit: Timmy LoenSee also: Visual: The hefty cost of credit card paymentsPlayers in the Asia Pacific are reacting to the fee revisions more subtly. In Singapore and Australia, Amazon customers who shop on local sites have to pay a surcharge when they use Visa credit cards at checkout.Beginning in October, GrabPay users in Singapore who make top-ups to their e-wallet via Visa credit cards have to pay extra after Grab imposed a surcharge of S$1 (US$0.73) on such transactions. (For top-ups worth over US$292, the super app absorbs the fees.)The Amazon-Visa stand-off, however, is significant for a few reasons, though it’s unclear why the payments firm was singled out. In an interview with the Financial Times, Visa CEO Al Kelly said it was “inaccurate” to call the cost of accepting payments in the UK as high and described the Amazon ban as “odd.” Fellow payment titan Mastercard reportedly also charges similar fees in the UK.Amazon holds considerable sway by virtue of its size: It commands 25% of the UK ecommerce market – or US$29 billion in volume, according to Euromonitor estimates. However, that figure is just 0.26% of Visa’s total.This scuffle also comes at a time when alternative payment methods such as digital wallets and buy now, pay later programs are growing popular.As these alternative methods proliferate and consumers get comfortable with having more options, merchants become less reliant on any one mode of payment.Amazon has little to lose from its move.Should Visa concede, Amazon benefits from more preferential rates, setting a precedent for other major retailers. If Visa doesn’t, the move is Amazon’s first step towards weaning itself off the payments network in the UK, as the e-retailer experiments with other payment options including BNPL and direct bank transfers through Venmo.The popular votePayment companies bumping up their fees isn’t new: Mastercard and Visa typically revise their fees twice a year.“It is a fairly common business practice for card schemes to make adjustments in interchange fees for various commercial reasons,” Aung Kyaw Moe, CEO of payment gateway 2C2P tells Tech in Asia. This might include compensating card issuers for the benefits – such as more attractive rewards or travel miles – that they offer to signature cardholders.There’s also a bigger price to pay for convenience. To make up for the higher fraud risks, for instance, interchange fees go up for “card-not-present” online checkouts compared to those made at the point of sale. Requiring less customer information might reduce friction for users at the checkout process, but it also cost smore in interchange fees due to the risk of bad debt.Despite the rise of QR code payments, credit card transactions remain dominant in Singapore. And in a highly carded market like Singapore, merchants have little choice but to offer card acceptance despite its costs, or risk losing customers.Spencer Wong, director of business development at local womenswear and lifestyle brand The Editor’s Market, says that credit and debit card payments account for most of its income. Apart from operating an online storefront and four retail outlets in Singapore, the company also has shops in the United Arab Emirates, Thailand, and Cambodia.By Invite Only, a Singapore-based jeweler, says it spends “close to 4%” of its annual revenue to accept electronic payments via credit and debit cards, which account for 86% of its transactions at its retail stores. GrabPay contributes 6%.While BNPL options and GrabPay make up a larger percentage – about 35% combined – of By Invite Only’s online transactions, credit card payments still make up for an overwhelming 65%. While offering as many options as possible is ideal, merchants have to avoid overcrowding the checkout process, Trixie Khong, the company’s founder and CEO, tells Tech in Asia.Khong believes local MDR rates aren’t competitively priced. “My estimate is that a fair price to transact would be between 0.5% to 1.5% depending on the service offered and if currency exchange was involved … [but] we are far away from that,” she adds.Opaque feesInterchange fees are a closely guarded trade secret. Set them too high and merchants are less likely to support card payments; set them too low and issuing banks have little incentive to market cards to users.In Singapore, this opaqueness has spurred calls for banks and payment firms to disclose what they charge as interchange fees. However, there’s no existing mandate for the disclosure of such fees.While a fee increase on ecommerce transactions (among other revisions) looms large in the US, Wong says he isn’t aware of similar fee hikes in Asia.But with the blended price plan that The Editor’s Market pays to an intermediary payments processing firm, Wong says it’s impossible to know if revisions have already been factored in.Like Amazon, super app Grab has encouraged users in Singapore to explore different options when topping up their wallets to avoid incurring the Visa-related fee. These include using credit cards from other payment networks, bank transfer service PayNow, or funds transfers from other GrabPay users.A customer using GrabPay at a store / Photo credit: GrabPayWhile the surcharge was initially set to take effect in June, it was postponed by four months to “ensure that more GrabPay top-up options would be in place” so that consumers could choose the most suitable option, Chris Yeo, managing director and head of GrabPay and GrabRewards at Grab Financial Group, tells Tech in Asia.Similarly, neobank YouTrip is set in December to begin imposing a 1.5% service fee on users adding funds via Visa credit cards. The company declined to be interviewed for this story.Of course, choosing which payment providers to work with isn’t always about prices.Aside from the method’s popularity, Wong also considers the ease of accounting, perks offered, and the scope for marketing collaborations.That view is echoed by Lenskart, a direct-to-consumer eyewear retailer based in Southeast Asia. “We look at aspects such as reach and user experience, which not only includes the user interface but also overall experience aspects, such as ease of handling refunds,” says Kaushal Bhalotia, the company’s chief digital officer for the region.Lenskart, which operates over 800 physical stores in Southeast Asia and South Asia, says it also considers ease of technical integration, account management or support provided, fraud handling, and also the ability to scale as the company expands to new markets.Is the end of credit cards nigh?Visa’s fee hike may be an opportunity for other payment providers to gain more traction.“Inevitably, any increase in interchange fees will be carried over to the merchants. Merchants who are cost-sensitive may decide to prioritize certain types of payment options,” 2C2P’s Aung adds. Ultimately, it is up to “merchants and their consumers to decide which payment option to choose at the point of check out.”Because payment gateway companies like Adyen and 2C2P support an array of methods – from those offered by card schemes to local e-wallets – they’re largely agnostic towards the types of payments that merchants use.Visa did not respond to Tech in Asia’s requests for comment on this story. Mastercard declined to comment on a list of questions sent by Tech in Asia.To be sure, Visa isn’t putting all its eggs in one basket. It’s investing aggressively beyond its fee-dependent core payments network, which may be usurped by new payment methods and crypto-based payment infrastructure.The payments company has also been investing in open-banking capabilities. With these features, consumers can connect their bank accounts directly to apps, potentially eliminating the need for cards entirely.In line with that, Visa recently acquired Sweden-based Tink and Australian-based Basiq, an API platform that lets fintech customers access data from their bank accounts.In addition, Visa is letting financial institutions add BNPL as an option for credit card holders. Acquirers on the network can also enable installments for retailers that accept Visa via a new solution.Mastercard has a BNPL program of its own as well. The company is working with digital asset exchange Bakkt to allow merchants, banks, and fintech firms on its network to accept payments in cryptocurrency.Ultimately, consumers will vote with their wallets, so retailers and the entire payment ecosystem have to follow. But as more people warm up to digital payments, BNPL, crypto, and other new means of payment, everyone wins.Currency converted from Singapore dollar and British pound to US dollar: US$1 = S$0.73; US$1 = £1.32.
excerpt: Amazon’s ban on Visa credit cards in the UK is a sign that the power balance between merchants, banks, and payment firms is shifting.
editor: Terence Lee and Eileen C. Ang

title: Visual: The hefty cost of credit card payments
content: Interchange fees – the rates set by companies like Visa and Mastercard for processing card transactions – have long been a flashpoint between the merchants who pay them to accept card payments, the banks that enable them, as well as the networks they ride on.These fees recently made the news after Amazon said it would ban UK-issued Visa credit cards next January, owing to Visa’s “high fees.”Interchange fees vary between geographies. In Europe, these can range from 0.3% to 0.4% of the transaction, while in the US, they average at 2%. In Singapore, interchange fees can range from around 2.5% to 2.8%, according to one retailer that Tech in Asia spoke to.While interchange fees are usually a relatively small percentage of the transaction, they can add up with the various other fees that apply to card payments.The fees are largely opaque, and in many markets, including Singapore, payment companies aren’t required to disclose publicly what they charge. In the European Union, the US, Australia, and Malaysia, there are caps to how much payment companies can charge.Interchange fees vary depending on a few factors, including:Card type: Fees are higher for credit cards compared to debit cards due to its associated credit risks.Premium vs basic card: Fees are higher for premium or signature cardholders, to compensate banks for providing more attractive rewards (e.g., miles).Online or offline transaction: Compared to physical checkouts, online or “card-not-present” transactions have larger fees due to the higher fraud risk.They’re also just one of many fees that a merchant has to fork out before they can accept card payments.To process card transactions, merchants pay their banks (“acquiring banks”) what’s known as a merchant discount rate (MDR). Interchange fees are just one component – albeit a significant part – of the MDR, and these are set by payment networks.To complicate things further, fee hikes are a fairly common business practice – Mastercard and Visa typically revise their fees twice a year for commercial reasons.Sometimes, these fees can be negotiated one-on-one depending on the size of the retailer and the volume of transactions they process, a practice that favors large marketplaces like Amazon. Small and medium-sized merchants, on the other hand, have comparatively little wiggle room in negotiating preferential rates.“Visa and Mastercard charge a consistent amount that is hard to negotiate because it really depends on transaction volumes,” Spencer Wong, director of business development at womenswear and lifestyle brand The Editor’s Market, tells Tech in Asia.“I believe it’s every retailer’s intention to negotiate for the lowest MDR where possible, and Visa [and] Mastercard could be more liberal in their pricing strategies,” Wong says. While “channels are open” with payment companies like Visa and Mastercard, “there’s little room to negotiate better rates,” he adds.With Amazon’s UK ban due to come into force in January next year, observers say there’s plenty of time for both parties to work toward a resolution. Whatever the eventual outcome, Amazon’s latest move sends an implicit signal to other retailers: diversify.CreditsEditing: Terence Lee and Lorenzo Kyle SubidoGraphics: Timmy Loen
excerpt: Ever wondered what goes behind the three seconds it takes for your card transaction to be approved?
editor: Terence Lee and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: 🇮🇳 Roundup: Flipkart enters grocery space with Shopsy, and more
content: Startups including Spry, Asqi, Insurance Samadhan, MasterChow, BharatX, and Evenflow collectively raised at least US$6.7 million today in disclosed funding from international and local investors.Here’s a snapshot of the fundraising:﻿﻿﻿Here’s some important tech news in India today:Flipkart enters grocery space with ShopsyEcommerce platform Flipkart is adding groceries to its suite of products on its social commerce platform Shopsy.It will feature around 6,000 products under 230 categories, which will be available for delivery to resellers across 700 cities.This move will pit Flipkart against Dealshare, Meesho, and Udaan in the grocery space.Open acquires neo-banking platform Finin for US$10 millionDigital bank Open will strengthen its cloud native enterprise with the acquisition of competitor Finin in a US$10 million cash-and-stock deal.Currently, Open powers nearly 2 million small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and processes over US$24 billion in annualized transactions.Founded in 2017, Open runs BankingStack, a cloud-native SME banking platform for financial institutions. Zwitch, a no-code embedded finance platform that is also operated by Open, will also benefit from the acquisition.Dailyhunt launches video app PublicvibeAfter filling in the TikTok void with video app Josh, Dailyhunt has reportedly launched hyperlocal video app Publicvibe.The video-only platform, which will feature location-based posts on crime, politics, public events, and issues, will go up against Inshorts’ Public.Publicvibe used to be known as NewsDistill when it was founded in 2015. It was then acquired by Dailyhunt in 2020.Follow the rest of our India coveragehere.
excerpt: Also, Open acquires neo-banking platform Finin for US$10 million, and Dailyhunt launches hyperlocal video app Publicvibe.
editor: Deepti Sri and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: Raining money: biggest exits in China
content: Sign up for the Daily Newsletter, sent exclusively to our Premium subscribers. We break down the big and messy topics of Asia’s tech and startup community. Get the newsletter in your inbox everyday with a Premium subscription.Hello reader,I was never able to speak Mandarin well. Back in school, I remember questioning why it was important for me to learn the language. One of the most common responses I got was that as China becomes a global business giant, just speaking English alone won’t cut it.For today’s story, we see just how big of a powerhouse it’s become through the lens of the country’s largest exits. It’s an impressive list, to say the least. From giants in ecommerce to fintech companies, the amount of money involved in these exits could make anyone’s eyes water.Today we look at,20 Chinese companies that got the biggest payouts from their exitsAn India-based logistics company getting more fuel in the tankOther newsy highlights such as Binance’s possible move in Indonesia and T11’s US$100 million round led by Alibaba. Premium summaryIn the midst of the Middle KingdomImage credit: Timmy LoenTo me, one of the most fascinating things about China is how the country’s businesses have effectively created their own ecosystem for everything from social media to streaming. For every Western company, there always seems to be a Chinese counterpart to serve the country’s users. Many of the companies on this list are responsible for providing these ecosystems.Who else…: Number one on the list is none other than Alibaba Group, following its US$21.8 billion IPO in 2014. This figure is more than the combined total value of exits for the next six companies on our list. It’s not the only time Alibaba makes an appearance either – its acquisition of mobile browser company UCWeb for US$1.9 billion places the latter at the number nine spot.Youku and chill: Video-streaming companies make three appearances in our top 10: Youku, Kuaishou, and iQiyi. Combined, these companies’ exits have netted them a juicy US$9.5 billion, a testament to the strength of the video-streaming market in the country.No victory too small: Rounding off our list is Qudian, an installment payment and investment management platform that was founded in 2014. Even though it comes in at 20th place, it still made US$900 million from its IPO in 2017.Read more: 20 largest exits in ChinaStartup spotlightTo infinity and beyondPhoto credit: ShiprocketIndia-based logistics aggregator Shiprocket is looking to blast off with the additional US$185 million raised during its series E funding round, led by Zomato, Temasek, and Lightrock India. Other participants in the round included existing investors InfoEdge Ventures and March Capital, as well as new investors Moore Strategic Ventures, 9unicorns, IndiaMart co-founder Brijesh Agrawal, and Lenskart founder Peyush Bansal.Shipping out goods: Founded in 2017, the startup provides tech-shipping and fulfillment services to SMEs, direct-to-consumer retailers, and social commerce sellers. Some of the items that it helps ship out include apparel, footwear, healthcare, and electronics, among others.Playing with the big boys: Apart from these services, it also helps retailers integrate their digital stores with large platforms such as Zoho, Shopify, and Magento. Through these integrations, retailers can manage orders, workflow, and inventory.Adding value: Shiprocket plans to use these new funds in several ways. First, it’s looking to expand its core product, conduct research and development, hire new talent, and improve its suite of services. Additionally, it will invest in hyperlocal delivery services for lower turnaround times on deliveries and put some of the new funding toward global expansion.Quick bytes1️⃣ Giving it a passShares for Society Pass, a Vietnam-based tech firm incorporated in the US, dipped 10% last Thursday amid weak Q3 results. According to the company, losses from operations grew by over 5x to reach US$8.4 million. This marks an overall loss of almost 90% of its stock value since last month, when the company first went public on the Nasdaq.2️⃣ Cashing outEmployees of Singapore telco firm Circles Life will soon be able to sell off their company stock options. The telco is currently planning to buy back US$5 million worth of these stocks, which are awarded to employees each year as part of its employee stock ownership plan. Staff members who have been with the company for a few years can expect to earn up to six figures in cash from this, according to Rameez Ansar, co-founder of Circles Life.3️⃣ Exploring Indonesian shoresCryptocurrency exchange Binance is in talks to open up an exchange in Indonesia, according to a Bloomberg report. It is currently discussing the move with state-owned Telkom Group and Indonesian financial institution Bank Central Asia (BCA), the latter of which may partner with Binance through another related firm.4️⃣ More excuses to play gamesAdoption of play-to-earn gaming in Southeast Asia got a boost after Yield Guild Games Southeast Asia raised US$15 million across two rounds of financing. Investors for the second round in November included Crypto.com Capital, Animoca Brands, and Bukalapak. The firm plans to focus on Indonesia, Vietnam, Singapore, and Thailand before expanding throughout Southeast Asia, with the additional funds being used to help deliver targeted offerings within the region.5️⃣ Boom boom powIndonesia-based insurtech firm Fuse has raised US$25 million in its series B+ round. The latest injection comes on top of the US$25 million it pulled in earlier this year. The company currently offers over 300 insurance products and has more than 30 partnerships with insurance companies. It plans to use the new funds to fuel expansion efforts in Southeast Asia.6️⃣ Speaking of AlibabaThe tech giant led a US$100 million series B round for T11, a China-based retail chain focused on fresh food and groceries. T11, which was founded in 2018, has opened eight stores across Beijing, Shanghai, and Wuhan and plans to upgrade its services with the new capital. Additionally, it’s looking to improve its supply chain, ecommerce platforms, and retail technology.
excerpt: We take a look at the Chinese companies that secured the biggest payouts from their exits and India-based Shiprocket’s US$185 million boost.
