title: Cars24 to go up against Carro, Carsome in SEA
content: India-based used-car marketplace Cars24 is set to compete against Singapore’s Carro and Malaysia’s Carsome as it expands into Southeast Asia with the launch of its operations in Indonesia in 2022, Nikkei Asia reported.SoftBank-backed Cars24 will invest US$100 million to fuel its expansion plans into newer international markets, after its foray into Australia and the United Arab Emirates in June.Cars24 aims to simplify the used car-selling process for its users by facilitating paperwork, including the transfer of certificates of registration, and enabling end-to-end transactions. It also sells pre-owned cars to businesses across India via its auction platform.See also: Carsome and Carro: A neck-and-neck race to transform how people buy carsThe company will use the earmarked funds to build a strong supply of cars for the platform and a create a workshop to recondition used cars.It will make its debut in two of Southeast Asia’s largest markets, Thailand and Indonesia, before branching out into the rest of the region.
excerpt: The India-based unicorn will make its debut in two of the region’s largest markets, Thailand and Indonesia, before expanding into the rest of the region.
tags: ['cars24', 'expansion', 'India', 'Indonesia', 'new briefing', 'Southeast Asia', 'Thailand', 'United Arab Emirates', 'used car marketplace']

title: Rebel Foods commits $150m for acquisitions, brands scale-up
content: Rebel Foods, an India-based cloud kitchen unicorn, has committed US$150 million in strategic brand investments and acquisitions globally.Food being prepared at a Rebel Foods cloud kitchen / Photo credit: Rebel FoodsThe amount will be used in the next few quarters to scale up existing and new partnerships with over 40 Indian and international brands. Under the initiative, it will invest, scale, and grow these food brands.Founded in 2011 by Jaydeep Barman and Kallol Banerjee, Rebel Foods is currently present in 10 markets – India, Indonesia, United Arab Emirates, the UK, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, Hong Kong, the Philippines, and Bangladesh – where it operates over 4,000 cloud kitchens.The startup’s operating system (OS) enables partner brands to scale up their presence across the Rebel network of over 70 cities, which it plans to grow to 100 cities globally.Rebel’s OS has three core components: culinary innovation and technology, end-to-end kitchen management technology, and a national supply chain. Rebel Foods has scaled brands like Slay, Naturals Ice Cream, Mad Over Donuts, and Wendy’s across multiple locations using its OS.See also: Cloud kitchen operator plots aggressive SEA expansion with unique approachIn October, the company raised US$175 million at a valuation of US$1.4 billion.
excerpt: The India-based cloud kitchen unicorn will use the money to scale up existing and new partnerships with over 40 local and international brands.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: AWS to invest $5b in Indonesia to set up cloud region
content: Global cloud service firm Amazon Web Services (AWS) launched a new cloud region in Indonesia called Asia Pacific (Jakarta). It allows the company’s customers to store their data in the country and serve local consumers with lower latency.A cloud region is the geographical location where the data or cloud centers are physically situated.Photo credit: Andy Hay / FlickrAWS also plans to invest around US$5 billion in Indonesia over the next 15 years, which includes spending for the construction of data centers, maintenance, and operational purposes. It estimated that the infrastructure will result in 24,700 direct and indirect jobs annually during the period.The company entered Indonesia with an office in 2018, which provides technical support to its customers. In March, AWS launched an edge location of Amazon CloudFront, its content delivery network, in the country.The Amazon subsidiary currently counts several Indonesian unicorns as its customers, including Tokopedia, Traveloka, and FinAccel.
excerpt: AWS estimates that the infrastructure for the new cloud region will result in 24,700 direct and indirect jobs annually over the next 15 years.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido

title: Fomo Pay to join DBS Bank’s crypto exchange
content: Singapore-based payment firm Fomo Pay is joining the DBS Digital Exchange (DDEx) by DBS Bank to let merchants accept payments in cryptocurrency from consumers “in a safe and risk-free manner.”Photo credit: Fomo Pay“Ultimately, this will lead to greater assurance and adoption of crypto as a form of payment method that will fit into Singapore’s vision to be a global crypto hub,” said Louis Liu, founder and CEO of Fomo Pay.In September, the fintech firm was granted three licenses by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for its merchant acquisition, domestic money transfer, and digital payment token services.Fomo Pay was founded in 2015 by Liu, who previously worked for Visa’s Asia-Pacific division, and Zack Yang, a venture partner at Teja Ventures.Meanwhile, DDEx earlier said that it holds S$600 million (US$438 million) worth of digital assets with at least 500 participants onboarded on its platform.In April, DBS teamed up with JPMorgan Chase and Temasek to form Partior, a crypto payment platform project.Currency converted from Singapore dollar to US dollar: US$1 = S$1.37
excerpt: The collaboration will allow Fomo Pay merchants to accept payments in cryptocurrency from customers.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['crypto currency', 'crypto exchange', 'DBS', 'dbs bank', 'DBS digital exchange', 'DDEx', 'fintech', 'fomo pay', 'Singapore']

title: Carousell HK, Atome, GoGoX join hands to serve local businesses
content: The Hong Kong unit of Carousell, the Singapore-based online classifieds giant, has teamed up with app-based logistics platform GoGoX and buy now, pay later firm Atome to provide services to local businesses via Carousell for Business (CarouBiz).Siu Rui Quek, Carousell’s co-founder and group CEO / Photo credit: HandoutCarousell and GoGoX have been working to provide logistics support to sellers through the latter’s GoGoVan and GoGoDelivery services, according to a statement. This comes in addition to its targeted logistics solution, GoGoBusiness, which includes order management and accounting features.Meanwhile, the Atome partnership will allow Carousell to offer its merchants a CarouBiz subscription package, allowingthem to split bills into three deferred payments upon checkout via credit card, debit card, or Apple Pay.Carousell users in Singapore will also see an upcoming recommerce partnership, said Jonathan Cai, Atome’s head of regional partnerships.See Also: Unpacking Carousell’s next big move: recommerceThe partnerships come after Carousell waltzed into the unicorn club after raising US$100 million in September. It then secured another US$10 million from Temasek-backed Heliconia in November.
excerpt: An Atome-powered BNPL feature that’s already available in Hong Kong will soon be brought to Carousell users in Singapore under an upcoming tie-up.

title: The hidden alliances between SEA’s VCs, uncovered (2021 edition)
content: You can view the actual number of co-investments by hovering over a colored square.Use the drop-down menu to reorder the matrix and explore the data. Best viewed on larger screens.Built with d3.js. Modified from Mike Bostock’s original les Misérables Co-occurrence.Data: Tech in AsiaInfographics: Ivan TanLast year, we dug deep into the relationship dynamics that drive Southeast Asia’s VCs.Peeling back the layers of the enigmatic VC scene, we uncovered how investors aligned themselves with each other and the different approaches they had toward co-investments.A year on, we’ve updated our matrix diagram. The graph is a visualization of startup co-investments over the past three years, and each colored cell represents two entities that co-invested in the same round. The darker the cell color, the more frequent those two entities co-invested together.This time, we’re curious to find out: Did the same alliances hold true? Are VCs sticking with the same buddies or growing their circles? Are there also new entrants that may potentially disrupt existing relationships?To answer these questions, we’ll examine Tech in Asia’s data on Southeast Asia’s funding rounds in 2021.A look at the leaderboardFirst off, we’ve noticed a significant reshuffling over the past year in the top 20 most active VCs in Southeast Asia in terms of deals made.New entrants in the roster include institutional investors like the Singapore Economic Development Board’s venture arm EDBI and Temasek Holdings, as well as VCs like Global Founders Capital, which previously focused more on other regions such as Europe.Temasek, in particular, has co-invested with Insignia Ventures Partners, Jungle Ventures, Sequoia Capital, and Wavemaker Partners. Some of its investments went to Indonesia’s GoTo, online fashion unicorn Zilingo, as well as a range of greentech startups such as alternative protein developer Growthwell Foods and waste management firm Lumitics.Deals that saw government-linked entities as co-investors also soared. Enterprise Singapore’s venture arm Seeds Capital, for example, nearly doubled its deal count for co-investments from 18 to 34.Although the top five most active investors have mostly kept their previous positions, the gap between each of them has significantly narrowed. Case in point: fifth-place Insignia Ventures Partners, which injected new capital into some of its portfolio companies via a recently closed investment vehicle, has reduced the gap with front-runner Sequoia Capital by nearly fivefold.VC circles got biggerIn our previous analysis, we identified different types of VC pairings and then labeled the ones with three co-investment deals or more together as intentional, rather than coincidental.This time, we wanted to investigate whether VCs have doubled down on their earlier co-investment buddies or teamed up with new ones.To do so, we calculated the standard deviation between the number of times a VC firm has co-invested with each of the other companies on the list. The higher the standard deviation, the deeper the relationships they’re likely to have.Here’s what we found among the top five most active investors.Compared to our previous analysis, the standard deviations of the top five VC firms suggest that they have become less agnostic over the past year.First off, the number of intentional VC pairings among the top five has skyrocketed from 19 to 75. This tells us that, over the last year, VCs have opened their doors to more co-investors.There’s also a higher number of pairings with more than three co-investment deals across the board, indicating that VCs also appear to be deepening relationships with new co-investors.On the whole, we found that the top five most active VCs made 42.4% more co-investment deals in 2021, adding up to 269 this year from 155 in 2020.Newcomers to the partyWho, then, are the new co-investors among the group? Here, government-linked entities are making a splash: Sequoia Capital partnered with EDBI the most, and the number of co-investments that Wavemaker Partners made with Seeds Capital is twice as many as the deals it made with its next highest co-investor.It isn’t just government-linked entities that are entering the fray, though. From what our data tells us, co-investments in Southeast Asia are coming from an increasingly diverse crowd.One such group of newcomers is Chinese corporations and VC firms like Kuaishou, ZhenFund, and Boyu Capital.With predominantly China-focused portfolios, their arrival in Southeast Asia could hint at their desire to look for investment opportunities abroad in industries that have been denied at home due to regulatory pressures.Another segment that’s making waves is the startup-turned-investor group like Indonesian fintech firms Payfazz and Ovo, as well as travel unicorn Traveloka.Payfazz has co-invested with Insignia Ventures Partners, while Ovo and Traveloka have co-invested with East Ventures. This could hint at the growing trend of VC-funded startups increasingly making their own bets in other startups in the region.As more investors enter Southeast Asia’s VC scene, being open to making new friends might be the way forward.
excerpt: Southeast Asian VCs are buddying up more, but newcomers look set to disrupt their relationships.

title: Zoomcar to pump $25m into Philippine launch
content: Zoomcar, an India-based car rental startup, has announced that it will launch its operations in the Philippines. The company plans to invest US$25 million in the next 12 months to fuel its expansion in the country.The startup has picked Gene Angelo Ferrer, the former country manager of logistics firm MrSpeedy, as its country head.Zoomcar CEO Greg Moran / Photo credit: ZoomcarEarlier this month, the firm launched its operations in Vietnam. This rollout is part of its US$100 million expansion plan into the Southeast Asian market for the next two or three years.See also: Indian car rental startup Zoomcar plans $100m bet in Southeast AsiaThe car rental firm will start its Philippine operations in Metro Manila, and it is set to launch in Cebu and Davao next year. The company plans to cover 20 cities in the country by 2023.Zoomcar aims to have 1,000 cars available for rent in the Philippines by January 2022, which will be scaled to 20,000 cars by the end of that year. In order to reach those figures, it will partner with individual car owners and small and medium-sized enterprises that have multiple vehicles.The company was founded by Greg Moran and David Back in 2013, with Back exiting the firm in 2015. Besides Southeast Asia, Zoomcar has also established operations in Egypt.The aggressive expansion into other countries comes ahead of the company’s plans to go public in the US by around August next year. Zoomcar is looking to raise a “nine-digit million number” in US dollars from its listing.
excerpt: IPO-bound Zoomcar aims to have 1,000 cars available for rent in the country by January 2022, which will be scaled to 20,000 cars by the end of that year.
editor: Collin Furtado and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['car rentals', 'Gene Angelo Ferrer', 'online car rental', 'Philippines', 'Zoomcar', 'Zoomcar philippines']

title: East Ventures leads pre-series A round of supply chain firm
content: Praktis (previously known as PTS.sc), an Indonesia-based supply chain solution for direct-to-consumer (DTC) brands, has raised an undisclosed amount of pre-series A funding in a round led by East Ventures, with participation from local conglomerate Triputra Group.(From left) Praktis co-founders Adrian Gilrandy, Dhimas Syahendra, Dipta Imanto, and Mohamad Fahrul / Photo credit: PraktisFounded in 2016, Praktis offers several services that can aid DTC brands in areas such as production, fulfillment, order management systems, and financing. The company also connects its clients to orders from corporates and government entities.The firm is founded by Dipta Imanto, Adrian Gilrandy,Dhimas Syahendra, and Mohamad Fahrul, with the first two both coming from Triputra Group.In 2021, Praktis said it recorded a 12x year-on-year growth in monthly revenue. Between January and September, the compound annual growth rate of the company’s revenue reached 24x.The firm plans to use the fresh funds for technology and hiring purposes.
excerpt: In 2021, Praktis said it recorded a 12x year-on-year growth in monthly revenue.
editor: Miguel Cordon and Lorenzo Kyle Subido
tags: ['Adrian Gilrandy', 'Dhimas Syahendra', 'Dipta Imanto', 'East Ventures', 'Indonesia', 'Mohamad Fahrul', 'praktis', 'Startup Funding', 'startups in indonesia', 'Triputra Group']
